Grammar Deep Dive: The 어? shows sudden understanding after someone explained or showed how to operate the device. 는 거고 confirms understanding while 죄송해요 apologizes for not knowing something basic. This shows Korean tendency to apologize when feeling they should have known something obvious.
Sentence 1
이거 물 때문에 그럴 거예요 아마
"This is probably because of water, I think"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun for nearby situation
• 물 - "water" - Noun
• 때문에 - "because of/due to" - Particle showing cause
• 그럴 거예요 - "it's probably like that" - 그렇다 (like that) + ㄹ 것 (probability) + 예요 (polite)
• 아마 - "probably/perhaps" - Adverb expressing uncertainty
Grammar Deep Dive: 때문에 indicates causation - the speaker is diagnosing a problem with the induction cooktop. ㄹ 거예요 expresses probability, while 아마 adds another layer of uncertainty, showing the speaker is making an educated guess but isn't completely sure.
Sentence 2
어우 죄송해요 제가 이거 꺼버렸어요 음 아니야 괜찮아 괜찮아 혹시 인덕션 쓸 줄 아세요?
"Oh my, I'm sorry. I turned this off. Hmm, no it's fine, it's fine. Do you know how to use the induction cooktop by any chance?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 어우 - "oh my/ugh" - Exclamation showing frustration or embarrassment
• 죄송해요 - "I'm sorry" - Formal polite apology
• 제가 - "I (humble subject)" - 저 (humble I) + 가 (subject particle)
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun
• 꺼버렸어요 - "turned off (unfortunately)" - 끄다 (turn off) + 버리다 (completive, regrettable) + 었어요 (past polite)
• 음 - "hmm" - Thinking sound
• 아니야 - "no/it's not" - 아니다 + 야 (casual)
• 괜찮아 - "it's fine" - 괜찮다 + 아 (casual), repeated for emphasis
• 혹시 - "by any chance" - Adverb for tentative requests
• 인덕션 쓸 줄 아세요? - "do you know how to use induction?" - 인덕션 + 쓰다 + ㄹ 줄 알다 + 세요
Grammar Deep Dive: 꺼버렸어요 uses 버리다 to show regret about the action - accidentally turning off the device. The mix of formal apology (죄송해요) and casual reassurance (괜찮아) shows multiple speakers or rapid shifts in tone. This captures the frustration and helpfulness in a group cooking situation.
Sentence 3
안 켜진 건가요? 응 안 켜졌어요
"It's not turning on? Yeah, it didn't turn on."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 안 - "not" - Negation adverb
• 켜진 건가요? - "is it turning on?" - 켜지다 (be turned on, passive) + ㄴ 것인가 (is it that?) + 요
• 응 - "yeah/uh-huh" - Casual affirmative response
• 안 켜졌어요 - "it didn't turn on" - 안 + 켜지다 + 었어요 (past polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: 켜지다 is the passive form of 켜다 - "be turned on" vs "turn on." The 건가요 structure seeks confirmation about a situation. The response 응 is casual while 켜졌어요 is polite, showing mixed formality levels in group conversation.
Sentence 4
해주세요 뭐지? 혹시 인덕션...
"Please do it. What is this? By any chance, the induction..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 해주세요 - "please do it" - 해주다 (do for someone) + 세요 (polite request)
• 뭐지? - "what is this?" - 뭐 (what) + 지 (wondering/questioning to oneself)
• 혹시 - "by any chance" - Tentative adverb
• 인덕션... - "induction..." - Trailing off, incomplete thought
Grammar Deep Dive: 해주세요 is a polite request for help. 뭐지 shows internal confusion or puzzlement. The trailing "인덕션..." suggests the speaker is trying to ask about the induction cooktop but gets distracted or interrupted. This shows natural, fragmented speech under stress.
Sentence 5
할 수 있으세요?
"Can you do it?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 할 수 있으세요? - "can you do it?" - 하다 (do) + ㄹ 수 있다 (can/able to) + 으세요 (polite honorific question)
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄹ 수 있다 expresses ability or possibility. The 으세요 ending shows respect for the addressee's capability. This is a polite way to ask if someone can help with the technical problem they're having.
Sentence 6
어? 됐다 어? 됐어요? 네
"Huh? It worked. Huh? Did it work? Yes."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 어? - "huh?" - Exclamation of surprise (repeated)
• 됐다 - "it worked/it's done" - 되다 (work/become) + 았다 (past casual)
• 됐어요? - "did it work?" - 되다 + 았어요 (past polite question)
• 네 - "yes" - Polite affirmative response
Grammar Deep Dive: The repeated 어? shows genuine surprise that the device suddenly worked. The shift from casual 됐다 to polite 됐어요 suggests either different speakers or the same speaker becoming more formal when confirming with others. This captures the relief when technical problems are solved.
Sentence 7
왜 안 되지? 물티슈 여기 있어요 아 어 여기도 있다
"Why isn't it working? Wet wipes are here. Ah, uh, there are some here too."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 왜 - "why" - Question word asking for reason
• 안 되지? - "isn't it working?" - 안 되다 (not work) + 지 (wondering/rhetorical question)
• 물티슈 - "wet wipes" - 물 (water) + 티슈 (tissue, English loanword)
• 여기 있어요 - "are here" - 여기 (here) + 있다 + 어요 (polite)
• 아 어 - "ah uh" - Hesitation sounds
• 여기도 있다 - "there are some here too" - 여기 + 도 (also) + 있다 (casual)
Grammar Deep Dive: 안 되지 is rhetorical frustration about something not working. The sudden mention of wet wipes suggests someone is trying to clean the cooktop surface (possibly to solve the water problem mentioned earlier). The conversation fragments show multiple people talking simultaneously.
Sentence 8
어? 안돼요? 어떤 요리를 하고 있을까?궁금해졌어
"Huh? It's not working? What kind of cooking are they doing? I became curious."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 어? - "huh?" - Surprise exclamation
• 안돼요? - "it's not working?" - 안 되다 + 어요 (polite question)
• 어떤 - "what kind of" - Question determiner
• 요리를 - "cooking (object)" - 요리 (cooking) + 를 (object particle)
• 하고 있을까? - "are they doing?" - 하다 + 고 있다 (continuous) + ㄹ까 (wondering)
• 궁금해졌어 - "I became curious" - 궁금하다 (curious) + 어지다 (become) + 었어 (past casual)
Grammar Deep Dive: 하고 있을까 wonders about ongoing action. 궁금해지다 means "to become curious" - the speaker's interest is piqued by the cooking situation. This suggests someone observing the kitchen chaos from outside and becoming interested in what's happening.
Sentence 9
아 인덕션 켜는 법을 모르셨군요? 어? 아세요? 아까 켠 거 아니에요?
"Ah, you didn't know how to turn on the induction cooktop? Huh? You know how? Didn't you turn it on earlier?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아 - "ah" - Realization interjection
• 인덕션 켜는 법을 - "how to turn on induction" - 인덕션 + 켜다 + 는 법 (method) + 을 (object)
• 모르셨군요? - "you didn't know?" - 모르다 (not know) + 셨 (past honorific) + 군요 (realization)
• 어? - "huh?" - Surprise
• 아세요? - "you know?" - 알다 (know) + 세요 (polite honorific)
• 아까 - "earlier/a while ago" - Time adverb
• 켠 거 아니에요? - "didn't you turn it on?" - 켜다 + ㄴ 것 + 아니에요 (negative question)
Grammar Deep Dive: 군요 shows realization about someone's situation. The rapid questioning (어? 아세요? 아까 켠 거 아니에요?) shows confusion as the speaker realizes their assumption was wrong. This captures the back-and-forth of people trying to figure out who can operate the equipment.
Sentence 10
아니요 아까... 이 양반들 나와보쇼
"No, earlier... Everyone, come out here"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니요 - "no" - Polite negative response
• 아까... - "earlier..." - Time reference, trailing off
• 이 양반들 - "these people/folks" - 이 (these) + 양반 (person, traditional term) + 들 (plural)
• 나와보쇼 - "come out and see" - 나오다 (come out) + 보다 (try/see) + 쇼 (polite imperative)
Grammar Deep Dive: 양반 is a traditional term meaning "gentleman" but used colloquially to mean "people/folks." 나와보쇼 is a polite but firm imperative - asking people to come help. This suggests someone calling for assistance from others who might be in different rooms.
Sentence 11
자 잠깐만요 이게 왜 안 켜지는... 이거 어떻게 하는거야?
"Wait, just a moment. Why won't this turn on... How do you do this?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 자 - "now/well" - Attention-getting interjection
• 잠깐만요 - "just a moment" - 잠깐 (moment) + 만 (just) + 요 (polite)
• 이게 - "this (subject)" - 이것 + 이 contracted
• 왜 - "why" - Question word
• 안 켜지는... - "won't turn on..." - 안 + 켜지다 (passive) + 는 (modifier), trailing off
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative
• 어떻게 하는거야? - "how do you do this?" - 어떻게 (how) + 하다 + 는 것 + 이야 (casual question)
Grammar Deep Dive: 잠깐만요 asks for patience while troubleshooting. The shift from polite (만요) to casual (거야) shows rising frustration. The trailing "안 켜지는..." suggests the speaker is puzzling over the problem while speaking.
Sentence 12
잠시만요 아휴 모르겠다 나는
"Just a moment. Ugh, I don't know."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 잠시만요 - "just a moment" - 잠시 (moment) + 만 (just) + 요 (polite)
• 아휴 - "ugh/sigh" - Exclamation of frustration or exhaustion
• 모르겠다 - "I don't know" - 모르다 (not know) + 겠다 (uncertainty/giving up)
• 나는 - "I (topic)" - 나 (I) + 는 (topic particle)
Grammar Deep Dive: 아휴 is a deep sigh of frustration. 모르겠다 with 겠 expresses giving up or admitting defeat. The 나는 at the end emphasizes the speaker's personal frustration - "as for me, I don't know." This shows someone reaching their limit with the technical problem.
Sentence 13
아 열올라. 안돼 안돼 ISTJ가 열받았어..! 안돼 ISTJ를 열받게 하면 안 돼..!
"Ah, I'm getting heated up. No, no, the ISTJ got angry..! No, you shouldn't make an ISTJ angry..!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아 - "ah" - Exclamation
• 열올라 - "getting heated up" - 열 (heat) + 오르다 (rise/come up), casual form
• 안돼 - "no/that's not okay" - 안 되다 + 어 (casual), repeated for emphasis
• ISTJ가 - "ISTJ (subject)" - MBTI personality type + 가 (subject particle)
• 열받았어..! - "got angry/heated" - 열받다 (get angry, slang) + 았어 (past casual)
• ISTJ를 - "ISTJ (object)" - ISTJ + 를 (object particle)
• 열받게 하면 안 돼..! - "shouldn't make angry" - 열받다 + 게 하다 (make someone) + 면 안 되다 (shouldn't)
Grammar Deep Dive: 열올라 and 열받다 are slang for getting angry/heated. The speaker is using MBTI personality types to explain the frustration - ISTJs are known for wanting things to work properly and getting frustrated with inefficiency. This shows Korean MBTI culture where personality types explain behavioral reactions.
Sentence 1
무섭다구!! 침착해~~ 제일 무서운 유형이라구..!!
"It's scary!! Calm down~~ It's the scariest type, I tell you..!!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 무섭다구!! - "it's scary, I tell you!!" - 무섭다 (scary) + 다구 (emphatic assertion ending) + !! (excitement)
• 침착해~~ - "calm down~~" - 침착하다 (be calm) + 해 (imperative) + ~~ (soothing elongation)
• 제일 - "most/number one" - Superlative adverb
• 무서운 - "scary" - 무섭다 + 은 (modifier form)
• 유형이라구..!! - "it's a type, I tell you..!!" - 유형 (type) + 이라구 (emphatic assertion) + ..!! (dramatic emphasis)
Grammar Deep Dive: 다구/라구 is an emphatic ending that insists on something being true - "I'm telling you!" The repeated exclamation marks and elongated sounds (~~) show high emotion. This refers to angry ISTJs being the "scariest type" in MBTI, continuing the personality type discussion with dramatic flair.
Sentence 2
좀 미래 지향적이고 아 이럴 거야 이렇게 될 거야 이런 사람들 보면은 짜증이 나요 막 왜지?
"A bit future-oriented, like 'ah, this will happen, it'll be like this' - when I see people like this, I get annoyed. Why?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 좀 - "a bit/somewhat" - Adverb meaning slightly
• 미래 지향적이고 - "future-oriented and" - 미래 (future) + 지향적 (oriented toward) + 이고 (and)
• 아 이럴 거야 - "ah, this will happen" - 아 (ah) + 이렇다 + ㄹ 거야 (will/prediction)
• 이렇게 될 거야 - "it'll be like this" - 이렇게 (like this) + 되다 + ㄹ 거야 (will become)
• 이런 사람들 - "people like this" - 이런 (this kind of) + 사람들 (people)
• 보면은 - "when I see" - 보다 (see) + 면 (when) + 은 (topic emphasis)
• 짜증이 나요 - "I get annoyed" - 짜증 (annoyance) + 이 나다 (come out/arise) + 요
• 막 - "just/randomly" - Emphasizing adverb
• 왜지? - "why?" - 왜 (why) + 지 (wondering to oneself)
Grammar Deep Dive: This describes N-type (iNtuitive) behavior that annoys S-types (Sensing). ㄹ 거야 shows future predictions, while 짜증이 나다 means "to get annoyed" (literally "annoyance arises"). The speaker is analyzing their own personality reaction and wondering why they feel this way about future-oriented thinking.
Sentence 3
왜 벌써 짜증을 내세요! 아직 안 싸웠어요! 쌈닭 여기 있었네
"Why are you already getting annoyed! We haven't fought yet! Oh, the seasoned chicken was here."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 왜 - "why" - Question word
• 벌써 - "already" - Adverb meaning sooner than expected
• 짜증을 내세요! - "you're getting annoyed!" - 짜증 + 을 내다 (express/show) + 세요 (polite)
• 아직 - "yet/still" - Adverb meaning up to now
• 안 싸웠어요! - "haven't fought!" - 안 (not) + 싸우다 (fight) + 었어요 (past polite)
• 쌈닭 - "seasoned chicken" - 쌈 (wrapping/seasoned) + 닭 (chicken)
• 여기 있었네 - "was here" - 여기 (here) + 있다 (exist) + 었 (past) + 네 (discovery/mild surprise)
Grammar Deep Dive: 짜증을 내다 means "to show/express annoyance." The sudden topic change to 쌈닭 (seasoned chicken) shows natural conversation flow where someone notices food while discussing personality conflicts. 네 ending shows discovery - "oh, it was here!" This captures how conversations shift between serious topics and practical matters.
Sentence 4
그래서 들으면 왜 이렇게 안일하게 생각하지? 그냥 생각을 조금 더 해서
"So when I hear that, why do they think so carelessly? Just think a little more and"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그래서 - "so/therefore" - Conjunction showing consequence
• 들으면 - "when I hear" - 듣다 (hear) + 으면 (when/if)
• 왜 - "why" - Question word
• 이렇게 - "like this/so" - Demonstrative adverb
• 안일하게 - "carelessly/complacently" - 안일하다 (complacent) + 게 (adverb form)
• 생각하지? - "do they think?" - 생각하다 (think) + 지 (rhetorical question)
• 그냥 - "just/simply" - Adverb
• 생각을 - "thinking (object)" - 생각 (thought) + 을 (object particle)
• 조금 더 해서 - "do a little more and" - 조금 (a little) + 더 (more) + 하다 + 어서 (and then)
Grammar Deep Dive: 안일하게 means "carelessly" or "too optimistically" - the speaker criticizes people who don't think thoroughly about consequences. This shows S-type (Sensing) preference for careful, detailed planning versus N-type (iNtuitive) broad-stroke future thinking. The rhetorical 지 expresses frustration with different thinking styles.
Sentence 5
확실하게 체크를 하고 넘어갈 수 있지 않나 이건 이제 제가 (MBTI를) 믿지는 않지만
"Can't we check it thoroughly and move on? This is - I don't really believe in MBTI, but"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 확실하게 - "thoroughly/certainly" - 확실하다 (certain) + 게 (adverb form)
• 체크를 하고 - "check and" - 체크 (check, English loanword) + 를 하다 + 고 (and)
• 넘어갈 수 있지 않나 - "can't we move on?" - 넘어가다 (move on/pass) + ㄹ 수 있다 (can) + 지 않나 (rhetorical question)
• 이건 - "this is" - 이것 + 은 contracted
• 이제 - "now/well" - Transition word
• 제가 - "I (humble subject)" - 저 + 가
• (MBTI를) - "MBTI (object)" - Parenthetical insertion
• 믿지는 않지만 - "don't really believe, but" - 믿다 (believe) + 지는 않다 (don't really) + 지만 (but)
Grammar Deep Dive: 지 않나 is rhetorical - "can't we?" showing the speaker thinks it's obvious. 지는 않지만 means "don't really... but" - showing ambivalence about MBTI while still using it to explain behavior. This demonstrates Korean skepticism mixed with practical use of personality frameworks.
Sentence 6
그냥 이렇게 사니까 이렇게 나오는 거 같은
"Since I just live like this, it seems like this is what comes out"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그냥 - "just/simply" - Adverb meaning casually
• 이렇게 사니까 - "since I live like this" - 이렇게 (like this) + 살다 (live) + 니까 (because/since)
• 이렇게 나오는 거 같은 - "it seems like this comes out" - 이렇게 + 나오다 (come out) + 는 것 같다 + 은 (modifier, trailing)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker suggests their MBTI results reflect their natural way of living rather than predetermined personality. 니까 shows causation, while 나오는 거 같은 trails off, suggesting incomplete thought. This reflects philosophical questioning about whether personality tests reveal innate traits or just current habits.
Sentence 7
근데 생각해 보니까 나랑 가장 안 맞을 거 같은 사람 한번씩 물어보지 않았어요?
"But thinking about it, didn't you ask once about the person who would be most incompatible with me?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 근데 - "but/however" - Casual form of 그런데
• 생각해 보니까 - "thinking about it/now that I think" - 생각해보다 (think about) + 니까 (since/because)
• 나랑 - "with me" - 나 (I) + 랑 (with, casual)
• 가장 - "most" - Superlative adverb
• 안 맞을 거 같은 - "wouldn't be compatible" - 안 맞다 (not match/fit) + ㄹ 것 같다 + 은 (modifier)
• 사람 - "person" - Noun
• 한번씩 - "once/at one point" - 한번 (once) + 씩 (each/at a time)
• 물어보지 않았어요? - "didn't you ask?" - 물어보다 (ask) + 지 않았다 (didn't) + 어요
Grammar Deep Dive: 생각해 보니까 shows reflection leading to realization. 안 맞다 means "not compatible/not match well." The speaker is recalling a previous conversation about MBTI compatibility, suggesting they want to revisit that topic. This shows how MBTI discussions often involve compatibility analysis.
Sentence 8
생각해 보니까 나 이거 이거라니 아니아니! E I 이거
"Thinking about it, me this this what do you mean! No no! E I this"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 생각해 보니까 - "thinking about it" - 생각해보다 + 니까 (since/because)
• 나 - "me/I" - First person pronoun
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative, repeated for emphasis
• 이거라니 - "what do you mean this!" - 이거 + 라니 (incredulous reaction)
• 아니아니! - "no no!" - 아니 (no) repeated for emphasis
• E I - "E I" - MBTI Extroversion/Introversion letters
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative referring to MBTI type
Grammar Deep Dive: 라니 expresses shock or disbelief - "what do you mean...!" The fragmented speech shows someone reacting emotionally to their MBTI type, possibly disagreeing with E (Extroversion) vs I (Introversion) classification. The repetition and exclamations show genuine surprise or disagreement with the results.
Sentence 9
이거라뇨! 이 분! 아니 아니 이거? 저거? 치울까요?
"What do you mean this! This person! No, no, this? That? Should I put it away?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 이거라뇨! - "what do you mean this!" - 이거 + 라뇨 (incredulous, more polite than 라니)
• 이 분! - "this person!" - 이 (this) + 분 (person, honorific) with exclamation
• 아니 아니 - "no no" - 아니 repeated
• 이거? - "this?" - Demonstrative with questioning tone
• 저거? - "that?" - Demonstrative for distant object
• 치울까요? - "should I put it away?" - 치우다 (put away/clean up) + ㄹ까요 (shall I?)
Grammar Deep Dive: 라뇨 is polite incredulity. The sudden shift from MBTI discussion to asking about putting something away (치울까요) shows natural conversation flow where practical matters interrupt theoretical discussions. This fragmented speech pattern is typical when multiple conversations happen simultaneously.
Sentence 1
이거 치워? 이거 치울까? 싸우기 전에 너 일로와 자!
"Put this away? Should I put this away? Before fighting, you come here!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun (repeated)
• 치워? - "put away?" - 치우다 (put away/clean up) + 어 (casual question)
• 치울까? - "should I put away?" - 치우다 + ㄹ까 (shall I?)
• 싸우기 전에 - "before fighting" - 싸우다 (fight) + 기 전에 (before doing)
• 너 - "you" - Second person pronoun (casual)
• 일로와 - "come here" - 이리 (here) + 오다 (come) + 아 (casual imperative)
• 자! - "come on!" - Casual imperative particle for encouragement
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker shifts from asking about cleaning to calling someone over before a "fight" (likely playful or competitive). 일로와 is a casual/dialectal form of 이리 와 (come here). The progression from question (치워?) to suggestion (치울까?) to command (일로와 자!) shows escalating directness.
Sentence 2
밥 못 먹겠는데? 미션을 해야지 저걸 켜주는 거 아니야? 밥은 먹을 수 있어요
"We can't eat? We should do the mission. Isn't that supposed to turn that on? We can eat rice."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 밥 - "rice/food" - Noun (general term for meal)
• 못 먹겠는데? - "can't eat?" - 못 (can't) + 먹다 (eat) + 겠 (ability/possibility) + 는데 (but/questioning)
• 미션을 - "mission (object)" - 미션 (mission, English loanword) + 을 (object particle)
• 해야지 - "should do" - 하다 + 야지 (should, with determination)
• 저걸 - "that thing (object)" - 저것 + 을 contracted
• 켜주는 거 아니야? - "isn't it supposed to turn on?" - 켜주다 (turn on for someone) + 는 것 + 아니야 (isn't it?)
• 밥은 먹을 수 있어요 - "we can eat rice" - 밥 + 은 (topic) + 먹다 + ㄹ 수 있다 + 어요
Grammar Deep Dive: This appears to be about a game or show where they need to complete missions to earn food. 못 먹겠는데 questions their ability to eat, while 해야지 shows determination to do the mission. 켜주는 거 아니야 asks about equipment operation. The contrast between casual (아니야) and polite (있어요) suggests multiple speakers.
Sentence 3
밥만 있거든.. 밥만 먹을 수 있어요 우린
"There's only rice, you know... We can only eat rice."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 밥만 - "only rice/food" - 밥 (rice/food) + 만 (only)
• 있거든.. - "there is, you know.." - 있다 (exist) + 거든 (explanatory, "you know") + .. (trailing)
• 밥만 먹을 수 있어요 - "can only eat rice" - 밥만 + 먹다 + ㄹ 수 있다 + 어요
• 우린 - "we" - 우리 (we) + 는 (topic particle) contracted
Grammar Deep Dive: 거든 is explanatory - "you know" or "because." The repetition of 밥만 (only rice) emphasizes their limited food options. This suggests they're in a controlled environment (like a reality show) where food options are restricted until missions are completed.
Sentence 4
아 이걸 동시에 누르면 되나?
"Oh, does it work if we press this at the same time?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아 - "oh" - Exclamation of realization
• 이걸 - "this (object)" - 이것 + 을 contracted
• 동시에 - "at the same time/simultaneously" - 동시 (simultaneous) + 에 (at/in)
• 누르면 - "if we press" - 누르다 (press) + 면 (if/when)
• 되나? - "does it work?" - 되다 (work/become) + 나 (questioning ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows problem-solving about operating some device or completing a task. 동시에 suggests coordination between multiple people. 되나 is casual questioning about whether something will work. This continues the theme of figuring out how to operate equipment or complete missions.
Sentence 5
저게 왜 안될까요?
"Why won't that work?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 저게 - "that (subject)" - 저것 + 이 contracted
• 왜 - "why" - Question word asking for reason
• 안될까요? - "won't it work?" - 안 되다 (not work) + ㄹ까요 (wondering, polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄹ까요 expresses polite wondering or speculation. The speaker is puzzled about why something isn't functioning. This continues the troubleshooting theme, showing ongoing technical difficulties with equipment or tasks.
Sentence 6
얘도 되는 거 같... 그렇다는 거 보니까 또 된다는 거 같은데 아닌가?
"This one seems to work too... Seeing that it's like that, it seems like it works again, or not?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 얘도 - "this one too" - 얘 (this, casual for 이것) + 도 (also)
• 되는 거 같... - "seems to work..." - 되다 + 는 것 같다 (seems like), trailing off
• 그렇다는 거 - "the fact that it's like that" - 그렇다 + 는 것 (nominalizer)
• 보니까 - "seeing that/when I see" - 보다 + 니까 (because/since)
• 또 - "again/also" - Adverb
• 된다는 거 같은데 - "it seems like it works, but" - 되다 + 는 것 같다 + 은데 (but)
• 아닌가? - "or not?" - 아니다 + ㄴ가 (questioning, seeking confirmation)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows uncertain observation and analysis. The speaker is trying to figure out patterns in how something works. 보니까 indicates inference from observation, while 아닌가 seeks confirmation of their uncertain conclusion. The hesitative language shows ongoing troubleshooting.
Sentence 7
비슷한 그림이 있어요
"There's a similar picture."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 비슷한 - "similar" - 비슷하다 (similar) + ㄴ (modifier)
• 그림이 - "picture (subject)" - 그림 (picture/drawing) + 이 (subject particle)
• 있어요 - "there is" - 있다 + 어요 (polite present tense)
Grammar Deep Dive: Simple observation about finding a similar image or diagram. This might be referring to instructions, game elements, or visual clues they're trying to match or follow. The polite tone suggests they're informing others about this discovery.
Sentence 8
확인 후 연락드리겠습니다 안되죠?
"I'll contact you after checking. That won't work, right?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 확인 후 - "after checking" - 확인 (confirmation/check) + 후 (after)
• 연락드리겠습니다 - "I will contact (you)" - 연락드리다 (contact, humble) + 겠습니다 (formal future)
• 안되죠? - "it won't work, right?" - 안 되다 (not work) + 죠 (seeking agreement)
Grammar Deep Dive: This sounds like formal business language (연락드리겠습니다) suddenly inserted into casual conversation, possibly someone mimicking official speech or reading from something. The contrast with casual 안되죠 creates humor through register mismatch.
Sentence 1
앉아계세요 전자레인지... 해보셨어요? 전자레인지로?
"Please sit down. Microwave... have you tried it? With the microwave?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 앉아계세요 - "please sit down" - 앉아있다 (be sitting) + 계시다 (honorific) + 세요 (polite request)
• 전자레인지... - "microwave..." - 전자 (electronic) + 레인지 (range) with trailing off
• 해보셨어요? - "have you tried it?" - 해보다 (try doing) + 셨어요 (past honorific polite)
• 전자레인지로? - "with the microwave?" - 전자레인지 + 로 (with/by means of)
Grammar Deep Dive: 앉아계세요 combines sitting (앉다) with the honorific 계시다, showing respect for the addressee. The trailing "전자레인지..." suggests the speaker is thinking or looking for alternatives. 해보셨어요 uses honorific past tense, showing polite inquiry about experience. This suggests exploring cooking alternatives when the induction cooktop isn't working.
Sentence 2
아니요... 여 여 여기서 검색하면 되지 않을까요? 여기서요?
"No... he- he- here, wouldn't it work if we search here? Here?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니요... - "no..." - Polite negative response with hesitation
• 여 여 - "he- he-" - Stuttering or hesitation sounds
• 여기서 - "here/from here" - 여기 (here) + 서 (from/at)
• 검색하면 - "if we search" - 검색하다 (search) + 면 (if/when)
• 되지 않을까요? - "wouldn't it work?" - 되다 (work) + 지 않을까요 (wouldn't it?/don't you think?)
• 여기서요? - "here?" - 여기서 + 요 (polite confirmation)
Grammar Deep Dive: The stuttering "여 여" shows nervousness or excitement. 되지 않을까요 is a polite way to suggest something - "don't you think it would work?" The repetition of 여기서/여기서요 shows emphasis and seeking confirmation. This suggests someone found a solution online or is suggesting to look something up.
Sentence 3
어 어 됐어요! 뭐야 어떻게 했어! 뭐야 어떻게 했어 어떻게 했어
"Uh uh, it worked! What? How did you do it! What? How did you do it, how did you do it"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 어 어 - "uh uh" - Hesitation or surprise sounds
• 됐어요! - "it worked!" - 되다 (work/become) + 았어요 (past polite)
• 뭐야 - "what?" - 뭐 (what) + 야 (casual exclamation)
• 어떻게 했어! - "how did you do it!" - 어떻게 (how) + 하다 + 았어 (past casual)
• 어떻게 했어 - "how did you do it" - Repeated for emphasis
Grammar Deep Dive: The excitement is shown through repetition and exclamation marks. 뭐야 shows surprise, while the repeated 어떻게 했어 shows intense curiosity about the method. The mix of polite (됐어요) and casual (했어) speech reflects high emotion where formality levels fluctuate. This captures the moment of breakthrough after technical difficulties.
Sentence 4
누가 했어? 이거 누르고 이거 누르면 돼요
"Who did it? Press this and press this and it works"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 누가 했어? - "who did it?" - 누가 (who, subject) + 하다 + 았어 (past casual)
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun (repeated)
• 누르고 - "press and" - 누르다 (press) + 고 (and)
• 누르면 돼요 - "if you press it works" - 누르다 + 면 (if) + 되다 + 어요
Grammar Deep Dive: 누가 했어 asks for credit/responsibility for the success. The explanation uses simple sequential instructions with 고 (and) followed by conditional 면 (if). This shows someone explaining the discovered solution step by step. The shift from casual question to polite explanation suggests addressing the group.
Sentence 5
아 동시에? 아~ 키는 방법이 이걸 키고 싶다 그러면 이걸 누르고 이걸 켠다?
"Oh, at the same time? Ah~ the way to turn it on is, if you want to turn this on, then you press this and turn this on?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아 동시에? - "oh, at the same time?" - 아 (oh) + 동시에 (simultaneously)
• 아~ - "ah~" - Extended realization sound
• 키는 방법이 - "the way to turn on" - 키다 (turn on) + 는 방법 (method) + 이 (subject)
• 이걸 키고 싶다 - "if you want to turn this on" - 이것 + 을 + 키다 + 고 싶다 (want to)
• 그러면 - "then/in that case" - Conditional conjunction
• 이걸 누르고 - "press this and" - 이것 + 을 + 누르다 + 고
• 이걸 켠다? - "turn this on?" - 이것 + 을 + 켜다 + ㄴ다 (casual declarative with questioning tone)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows someone understanding the operating procedure. 키는 방법 means "method of turning on." The conditional structure (고 싶다 그러면) explains the logical sequence. The questioning tone at the end seeks confirmation of understanding. 키다 and 켜다 are both used for "turn on" - showing natural variation in Korean.
Sentence 6
아~ 그런 거구나! 오 천재
"Ah~ that's how it is! Oh, genius"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아~ - "ah~" - Extended realization sound
• 그런 거구나! - "that's how it is!" - 그런 것 (that kind of thing) + 구나 (realization exclamation)
• 오 - "oh" - Exclamation of admiration
• 천재 - "genius" - Noun meaning genius or brilliant person
Grammar Deep Dive: 구나 is the realization ending - "I see!" or "so that's how it is!" The speaker finally understands the solution. 천재 is praise for whoever figured it out. This captures the "aha moment" when technical problems are solved, showing Korean appreciation for cleverness.
Sentence 7
감격스러워 똑똑하시네 됐네 해결됐네 진짜 최고 X3
"I'm so moved. You're smart. It worked. It's solved. Really the best x3"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 감격스러워 - "I'm moved/emotional" - 감격스럽다 (moving/touching) + 어 (casual)
• 똑똑하시네 - "you're smart" - 똑똑하다 (smart) + 시 (honorific) + 네 (admiration)
• 됐네 - "it worked" - 되다 + 았 + 네 (casual observation)
• 해결됐네 - "it's solved" - 해결되다 (be solved) + 았 + 네
• 진짜 - "really" - Adverb meaning truly
• 최고 - "the best" - Superlative meaning highest/best
• X3 - "x3" - Multiplication notation showing emphasis or repetition
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows overwhelming relief and gratitude. 감격스럽다 means deeply moved or emotional. The 네 endings show casual observation with mild surprise. X3 is internet/gaming notation meaning "times three" - emphasizing the praise. The rapid succession of positive expressions shows Korean tendency to express appreciation abundantly.
Sentence 8
우리 5일 동안 콘푸로스트만 먹을 뻔 했는데 그거 연락 취소해야 되는 거 아니에요?
"We almost had to eat only corn flakes for 5 days, but shouldn't we cancel that contact?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 우리 - "we" - First person plural pronoun
• 5일 동안 - "for 5 days" - 5일 (5 days) + 동안 (during/for)
• 콘푸로스트만 - "only corn flakes" - 콘푸로스트 (corn flakes, likely Korean brand) + 만 (only)
• 먹을 뻔 했는데 - "almost had to eat" - 먹다 + ㄹ 뻔하다 (almost did) + 았는데 (past, but)
• 그거 - "that" - Demonstrative pronoun
• 연락 - "contact/communication" - Noun
• 취소해야 되는 거 아니에요? - "shouldn't we cancel?" - 취소하다 (cancel) + 야 되다 (should) + 는 것 + 아니에요 (isn't it?)
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄹ 뻔하다 means "almost did" - expressing relief about avoiding something bad. 콘푸로스트 appears to be a Korean corn flakes brand. The reference to canceling "that contact" suggests they had called for help (maybe technical support or food delivery) which is no longer needed since they solved the problem. This shows practical Korean thinking - cleaning up unnecessary actions after problem resolution.
Sentence 1
다행이다 해결 됐다고... 아니 왜냐하면 방금 딱 그 말을 하는데 너무 나인거야
"Thank goodness it's solved... No, because just now when you said exactly that, it was so me"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 다행이다 - "thank goodness/fortunately" - 다행 (good fortune) + 이다 (is)
• 해결 됐다고... - "it's solved..." - 해결 (solution) + 되다 (become) + 았다고 (quotative) with trailing
• 아니 - "no/wait" - Interjection
• 왜냐하면 - "because" - Formal conjunction for explanation
• 방금 - "just now" - Time adverb meaning moments ago
• 딱 - "exactly/precisely" - Adverb for emphasis
• 그 말을 하는데 - "when saying that" - 그 말 (those words) + 을 하다 (say) + 는데 (while/when)
• 너무 나인거야 - "it was so me" - 너무 (so) + 나 (me) + 인 것 + 이야 (casual assertion)
Grammar Deep Dive: 다행이다 expresses relief. The speaker shifts from relief about the solved problem to self-reflection, recognizing they relate strongly to something just said. "너무 나인거야" means "it's so me" - showing strong personal identification. This suggests connection to previous MBTI personality discussion.
Sentence 2
막 약간 상상도 많구 이러면 어떨까 저러면 어떨까? 공황 터질 거 같은 거에요
"I have a lot of imagination and think 'what if this, what if that?' It feels like I might have a panic attack"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 막 - "just/really" - Emphasizing adverb
• 약간 - "somewhat/kind of" - Adverb meaning slightly
• 상상도 많구 - "have a lot of imagination too" - 상상 (imagination) + 도 (also) + 많다 + 구 (casual ending)
• 이러면 어떨까 - "what if this happens" - 이렇다 (like this) + 면 (if) + 어떨까 (how would it be)
• 저러면 어떨까? - "what if that happens?" - 저렇다 (like that) + 면 + 어떨까
• 공황 - "panic" - Noun meaning panic attack
• 터질 거 같은 거에요 - "feels like it might explode/happen" - 터지다 (explode/burst) + ㄹ 것 같다 + 은 것 + 에요
Grammar Deep Dive: This describes anxiety-inducing overthinking patterns. 이러면/저러면 어떨까 shows hypothetical worrying - "what if this/that." 터지다 means "explode" or "burst out" - used metaphorically for panic attacks. This reveals the speaker's anxiety about their imaginative, worrying tendencies (classic N-type overthinking).
Sentence 3
그래가지고 아까 조용히 방 들어가서 약 하나 먹고 왔어요
"So I quietly went into the room and took some medicine"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그래가지고 - "so/because of that" - 그래서 + 가지고 (casual connective)
• 아까 - "earlier/a while ago" - Time adverb
• 조용히 - "quietly" - 조용하다 (quiet) + 히 (adverb form)
• 방 - "room" - Noun
• 들어가서 - "going in" - 들어가다 (enter) + 어서 (and then)
• 약 하나 - "one medicine/pill" - 약 (medicine) + 하나 (one)
• 먹고 왔어요 - "took and came back" - 먹다 (eat/take) + 고 오다 (come after doing) + 었어요
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows the speaker took anxiety medication due to earlier stress. 그래가지고 is casual causation. 먹고 오다 means "take and come back" - showing a quick, discrete action. This demonstrates Korean openness about mental health management.
Sentence 4
진짜로?
"Really?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 진짜로? - "really?" - 진짜 (really) + 로 (adverb marker) + questioning tone
Grammar Deep Dive: Simple surprised reaction to learning about the medication. Shows another person's reaction to the previous statement about taking anxiety medication.
Sentence 5
지금 괜찮으세요?
"Are you okay now?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 지금 - "now" - Time adverb
• 괜찮으세요? - "are you okay?" - 괜찮다 (be fine) + 으세요 (honorific polite question)
Grammar Deep Dive: Shows caring inquiry using honorific form. 괜찮다 means "be okay/fine." This demonstrates Korean concern for others' wellbeing after learning about their anxiety.
Sentence 6
지금은 괜찮아요 이제 계획대로 잘 풀려서 아 뭐 하나 마실까요 우리?
"I'm fine now. Since things are working out well according to plan, ah, shall we drink something?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 지금은 괜찮아요 - "I'm fine now" - 지금 + 은 (topic) + 괜찮다 + 아요
• 이제 - "now/at this point" - Temporal transition word
• 계획대로 - "according to plan" - 계획 (plan) + 대로 (according to)
• 잘 풀려서 - "working out well" - 잘 (well) + 풀리다 (be solved/work out) + 어서 (so/because)
• 아 - "ah" - Interjection
• 뭐 하나 마실까요 - "shall we drink something" - 뭐 (something) + 하나 (one) + 마시다 (drink) + ㄹ까요
• 우리? - "we?" - First person plural with questioning tone
Grammar Deep Dive: Shows relief response and social bonding suggestion. 대로 means "according to" or "as planned." 풀리다 means "be solved" or "work out smoothly." The suggestion to drink something is typical Korean social bonding after stress resolution.
Sentence 7
목 안 마르세요 다들?
"Aren't you all thirsty?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 목 - "throat" - Noun
• 안 마르세요 - "aren't thirsty" - 안 (not) + 마르다 (dry/be thirsty) + 세요 (honorific polite)
• 다들? - "everyone?" - 다 (all) + 들 (plural) + questioning tone
Grammar Deep Dive: 목이 마르다 literally means "throat is dry" = "be thirsty." The negative question form suggests the speaker expects people to be thirsty. This continues the Korean hospitality pattern of offering drinks.
Sentence 8
뭐 마시실 분~
"Anyone want to drink something~"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 뭐 - "something" - Pronoun
• 마시실 분~ - "person who will drink~" - 마시다 + 실 (honorific future) + 분 (person) + ~ (drawn out, inviting tone)
Grammar Deep Dive: 마시실 분 is formal/polite way to ask "who wants to drink" using honorific 실. The elongated ~ creates a friendly, inviting atmosphere typical of Korean hospitality.
Sentence 9
안녕하세요 저는 진자림입니다
"Hello, I'm Jinjarlim"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 안녕하세요 - "hello" - Standard polite greeting
• 저는 - "I am (humble)" - 저 (humble I) + 는 (topic particle)
• 진자림입니다 - "I'm Jinjarlim" - Name + 입니다 (formal polite copula)
Grammar Deep Dive: Standard formal self-introduction using humble language. This appears to be introducing themselves to a new person or perhaps reintroducing for clarity.
Sentence 10
미국애들도 I 이런 사람들은
"American kids too, I-type people like this..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 미국애들도 - "American kids too" - 미국 (America) + 애들 (kids, casual) + 도 (also)
• I - "I" - MBTI Introversion type
• 이런 사람들은 - "people like this" - 이런 (this kind of) + 사람들 (people) + 은 (topic)
Grammar Deep Dive: Beginning of a question about cross-cultural MBTI patterns. 애들 is casual for "kids/people." The speaker is asking whether American introverts (I-types) behave similarly to Korean introverts.
Sentence 11
막 내향적이고 이럴까요?
"Are they introverted and like this?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 막 - "just/really" - Emphasizing adverb
• 내향적이고 - "introverted and" - 내향적 (introverted) + 이고 (and)
• 이럴까요? - "are they like this?" - 이렇다 + ㄹ까요 (wondering)
Grammar Deep Dive: Continuation of the cross-cultural question about American personality types. 내향적 means "introverted." The speaker is wondering if American I-types show similar introverted behaviors.
Sentence 12
네 걔네도 그런 애들이 있어요?
"Yes, do they also have kids like that?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 네 - "yes" - Affirmative response
• 걔네도 - "they too" - 걔네 (those kids, casual) + 도 (also)
• 그런 애들이 있어요? - "are there kids like that?" - 그런 (that kind of) + 애들 + 이 있다 + 어요
Grammar Deep Dive: 걔네 is casual for "those people/kids." The question continues exploring whether introverted personality types exist in American culture, challenging potential stereotypes about Americans being uniformly extroverted.
Sentence 13
많아요 막 다 활발하고 이런 애들이 아니고?
"Are there many? Aren't they all lively and outgoing kids?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 많아요 - "are there many?" - 많다 + 아요 (polite)
• 막 다 - "just all" - 막 (just) + 다 (all)
• 활발하고 - "lively and" - 활발하다 (lively/active) + 고 (and)
• 이런 애들이 아니고? - "aren't they kids like this?" - 이런 애들 + 이 아니다 + 고 (questioning)
Grammar Deep Dive: This reveals Korean stereotypes about Americans being outgoing/extroverted (활발하다). The questions show genuine curiosity about whether introversion exists in American culture or if the stereotype of Americans being uniformly outgoing is accurate. This reflects Korean interest in cultural personality differences.
Sentence 1
네 없어요 이게 진짜 걔네들도 사람이더라고 다 똑같구나 사람 사는 거
"Yeah, there isn't... This is really, those people are human too, you know. Everyone's all the same - living as humans."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 네 - "yes/yeah" - Casual acknowledgment or agreement
• 없어요 - "there isn't/don't have" - 없다 (to not exist) + 어요 (polite ending)
• 이게 - "this is" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject marker, contracted)
• 진짜 - "really/truly" - Informal intensifier, stronger than 정말
• 걔네들도 - "those people too" - 걔네들 (those guys/people, casual) + 도 (also/too)
• 사람이더라고 - "are human, you know" - 사람 (person) + 이다 (to be) + 더라고 (past realization/discovery ending)
• 다 - "all/everything" - Adverb meaning completely or entirely
• 똑같구나 - "are all the same" - 똑같다 (to be the same) + 구나 (realization exclamation)
• 사람 사는 거 - "living as humans/human life" - 사람 (person) + 살다 (to live) + 는 것 (nominalizing ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This sentence shows very casual, stream-of-consciousness speech. 더라고 expresses a past realization - the speaker discovered something about these people. 구나 shows sudden realization or exclamation. The fragmented structure (starting with 네 없어요) suggests interrupted or conversational speech, typical in Korean casual dialogue. The use of 걔네들 (casual "those people") shows the speaker's informal attitude.
Sentence 2
I 방 Introversion : 내향형 기 빨렸어 나는 사람과의 모임은 4시간이 한계야..
"I-type Introversion: I'm drained of energy. For me, social gatherings have a 4-hour limit.."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• I 방 - "I-type" - MBTI terminology mixing English "I" (Introversion) with Korean
• 내향형 - "introverted type" - 내향 (inward-facing) + 형 (type/form)
• 기 빨렸어 - "energy drained" - 기 (energy/spirit) + 빨리다 (to be sucked out) + 었어 (past casual)
• 나는 - "I (as for me)" - 나 (I) + 는 (topic particle, emphasizing contrast)
• 사람과의 - "with people" - 사람 (person) + 과 (with) + 의 (possessive/connecting)
• 모임은 - "gatherings/meetings" - 모임 (gathering) + 은 (topic particle)
• 4시간이 - "4 hours" - 4시간 (4 hours) + 이 (subject particle)
• 한계야 - "is the limit" - 한계 (limit/boundary) + 야 (casual declarative ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This mixes Korean with MBTI English terminology, showing modern Korean internet culture. 기 빨렸어 is a very colloquial expression meaning "energy drained" - 빨리다 literally means "to be sucked" but here refers to energy being depleted. The speaker uses 나는 to emphasize personal experience contrasting with others. The casual 야 ending shows informal, personal reflection typical in online personality discussions.
Sentence 3
원래라면 집에 가야 되는데 집에 갈 수 없군
"Normally I should go home, but I can't go home."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 원래라면 - "if it were normal/originally" - 원래 (originally) + 라면 (conditional "if")
• 집에 - "to home" - 집 (house/home) + 에 (direction particle)
• 가야 되는데 - "should go, but" - 가다 (to go) + 야 되다 (should/must) + 는데 (contrasting conjunction)
• 집에 - "to home" - Same as above, repeated for emphasis
• 갈 수 없군 - "can't go" - 가다 (to go) + ㄹ 수 없다 (cannot) + 군 (realization/observation ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 야 되다 expresses obligation or necessity, more colloquial than 아야 하다. The 는데 conjunction sets up a contrast between expectation (should go home) and reality (can't go). 군 ending shows the speaker's realization or observation about their situation, often with a slightly resigned tone. The repetition of 집에 emphasizes the home destination and the speaker's frustration.
Sentence 4
PD님들 말도 못 하시고 담배 피시게요? 아니요
"The PDs can't even speak and you're smoking? No."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• PD님들 - "PD-nims/PDs" - PD (Program Director) + 님 (honorific suffix) + 들 (plural)
• 말도 - "even speaking" - 말 (words/speaking) + 도 (even/also, emphasizing)
• 못 하시고 - "can't do and" - 못 (cannot) + 하다 (to do) + 시 (honorific) + 고 (and/connector)
• 담배 - "cigarette" - Noun
• 피시게요? - "are you smoking?" - 피우다 (to smoke) + 시 (honorific) + 게요 (questioning/casual polite ending)
• 아니요 - "no" - Polite negative response
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker uses honorifics (님, 시) when referring to the PDs, showing respect for their position. 말도 못 하다 is an idiomatic expression meaning "can't even speak" - often used when someone is overwhelmed or speechless. The contrast between using honorifics and the somewhat accusatory tone suggests a complex social dynamic, possibly in a work/broadcast environment.
Sentence 5
내가 볼 때 INFP 님이 게임을 좋아하시기 때문에 게임 이야기해 그러면 티츄를 하자고 그러면
"From what I can see, since INFP-nim likes games, if we talk about games, then suggest playing Tichu, then..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 내가 볼 때 - "from what I can see/in my opinion" - 내가 보다 (I see) + ㄹ 때 (when/from the perspective of)
• INFP 님이 - "INFP-nim" - MBTI type + honorific 님 + subject particle 이
• 게임을 - "games (object)" - 게임 (game) + 을 (object particle)
• 좋아하시기 때문에 - "because (they) like" - 좋아하다 (to like) + 시 (honorific) + 기 때문에 (because)
• 게임 이야기해 - "talk about games" - 게임 (game) + 이야기하다 (to talk) casual form
• 그러면 - "then/if so" - Conditional connector
• 티츄를 - "Tichu (object)" - Card game name + object particle
• 하자고 - "let's do/suggest doing" - 하다 (to do) + 자고 (suggestion ending)
• 그러면 - "then" - Repeated conditional connector showing sequence
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows strategic thinking and social planning. The speaker maintains honorifics (님, 시) when referring to the INFP person. 자고 하다 is used for suggestions ("let's do X"). The repeated 그러면 creates a logical sequence of if-then scenarios. The sentence structure reflects Korean tendency for complex conditional reasoning and social consideration in conversation planning.
Sentence 6
보드게임을 하자 그러면 할 수도 있어 티츄 아세요? 티츄가 바로 INTJ 용 게임이랍니다
"Let's play board games, then we might be able to play. Do you know Tichu? Tichu is exactly a game for INTJs, you know."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 보드게임을 - "board games (object)" - 보드게임 (board game) + 을 (object particle)
• 하자 - "let's do" - 하다 (to do) + 자 (suggestion ending)
• 그러면 - "then/if so" - Conditional connector
• 할 수도 있어 - "might be able to do" - 하다 (to do) + ㄹ 수 있다 (can/able) + 도 (even/also, possibility)
• 티츄 - "Tichu" - Card game name
• 아세요? - "do you know?" - 알다 (to know) + 세요 (polite question ending)
• 티츄가 - "Tichu (subject)" - Game name + subject particle
• 바로 - "exactly/precisely" - Adverb for emphasis
• INTJ 용 - "for INTJ" - MBTI type + 용 (for/use)
• 게임이랍니다 - "it's a game, you know" - 게임 (game) + 이다 (to be) + 랍니다 (explanatory/informative ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker switches between casual (하자, 있어) and polite (아세요, 이랍니다) forms, showing social awareness. 랍니다 is an informative ending that presents information as if sharing knowledge, often with a slightly proud or explanatory tone. The use of 바로 emphasizes the perfect match between the game and personality type, showing the speaker's confidence in their MBTI-gaming theory.
Sentence 7
왜요? 게임이 게임에서도 MBTI 성향이 좀 갈려요
"Why? Even in games, MBTI tendencies get somewhat divided."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 왜요? - "why?" - 왜 (why) + 요 (polite ending for questions)
• 게임이 - "games (subject)" - 게임 (game) + 이 (subject particle)
• 게임에서도 - "even in games" - 게임 (game) + 에서 (in/at) + 도 (even/also)
• MBTI - "MBTI" - Myers-Briggs Type Indicator
• 성향이 - "tendencies/inclinations" - 성향 (tendency/inclination) + 이 (subject particle)
• 좀 - "somewhat/a bit" - Adverb for mild degree
• 갈려요 - "get divided/split" - 갈리다 (to be divided/split) + 어요 (polite ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 갈리다 means "to be split/divided" and is often used metaphorically for opinions, preferences, or groups being divided. The speaker uses 좀 to soften the statement, making it less absolute. This reflects Korean communication style of avoiding overly strong assertions. The repetition of 게임 (게임이 게임에서도) emphasizes the gaming context while creating natural speech rhythm.
Sentence 1
에이 INTJ 가 좋아할 만한 게임은 전략적인 게임 바로 티츄!
"Ay, the kind of game that INTJs would like is strategic games - exactly Tichu!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 에이 - "ay/hey" - Interjection expressing mild dismissal or emphasis
• INTJ 가 - "INTJs (subject)" - MBTI personality type + subject particle
• 좋아할 만한 - "would like/the kind that would be liked" - 좋아하다 (to like) + ㄹ 만하다 (worthy of/likely to)
• 게임은 - "games (topic)" - 게임 (game) + 은 (topic particle)
• 전략적인 - "strategic" - 전략 (strategy) + 적 (suffix making adjective) + 인 (adjectival ending)
• 게임 - "game" - Noun
• 바로 - "exactly/precisely" - Adverb for emphasis
• 티츄! - "Tichu!" - Card game name with exclamation
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄹ 만하다 is a useful construction meaning "worthy of" or "likely to" - here expressing that strategic games are the type INTJs would naturally gravitate toward. The speaker uses 에이 as a casual interjection, showing confidence in their assessment. The structure builds anticipation with 게임은...게임 before the dramatic reveal with 바로 티츄, creating emphasis through repetition and positioning.
Sentence 2
지금 하게요? 아뇨 보여만 주려고요 아 맞아 어 깜짝아 어 나 진짜 중요한 거 있었는데 말 안 하고 있었어
"Are we playing now? No, I'm just going to show you. Ah right, uh, oh my! Uh, I had something really important but I wasn't saying it."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 지금 - "now" - Time adverb
• 하게요? - "shall we do?" - 하다 (to do) + 게요 (casual polite question ending)
• 아뇨 - "no" - Polite negative response
• 보여만 - "just show" - 보여주다 (to show) + 만 (only/just)
• 주려고요 - "going to give/show" - 주다 (to give) + 려고 (intention) + 요 (polite ending)
• 아 맞아 - "ah right" - Interjections showing sudden remembering
• 어 - "uh" - Filler word, hesitation
• 깜짝아 - "oh my!/surprise!" - Exclamation of sudden realization
• 나 - "I" - First person pronoun (casual)
• 진짜 - "really" - Intensifier (casual)
• 중요한 거 - "important thing" - 중요하다 (important) + ㄴ (adjectival) + 것 (thing)
• 있었는데 - "there was, but" - 있다 (to exist) + 었 (past) + 는데 (contrasting conjunction)
• 말 안 하고 있었어 - "wasn't saying" - 말하다 (to speak) + 안 (not) + 하고 있다 (continuous) + 었어 (past casual)
Grammar Deep Dive: This sentence captures natural speech patterns with multiple interjections (아, 어, 깜짝아) showing the speaker's stream of consciousness. 려고 indicates intention or purpose. The 는데 conjunction sets up contrast between having something important to say versus not saying it. The casual tone (나, 진짜, 었어) shows comfortable, informal speech typical among friends or peers.
Sentence 3
뭐죠? 와 이거 카메라 돌아가고 있는 거 맞나? 이거는 사실 카메라 돌아갈 때 말해야 되는 아주 중대한 사항인데
"What is it? Wow, is this camera really rolling? This is actually a very important matter that should be said when the camera is rolling."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 뭐죠? - "what is it?" - 뭐 (what) + 죠 (polite questioning particle)
• 와 - "wow" - Exclamation of surprise or realization
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun (casual)
• 카메라 - "camera" - Noun
• 돌아가고 있는 거 - "is rolling/running" - 돌아가다 (to turn/run) + 고 있다 (continuous) + 는 것 (nominalizing)
• 맞나? - "is it right?" - 맞다 (to be correct) + 나 (questioning particle, casual)
• 이거는 - "this (topic)" - 이것 (this) + 는 (topic particle)
• 사실 - "actually/in fact" - Adverb
• 카메라 - "camera" - Repeated for emphasis
• 돌아갈 때 - "when rolling" - 돌아가다 (to run) + ㄹ 때 (when)
• 말해야 되는 - "should say" - 말하다 (to speak) + 아야 되다 (should/must) + 는 (adjectival ending)
• 아주 - "very/quite" - Intensifying adverb
• 중대한 - "important/serious" - 중대 (importance/gravity) + 한 (adjectival ending)
• 사항인데 - "matter, but" - 사항 (matter/item) + 인데 (explanatory/contrasting ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker shows awareness of being recorded, evident in the meta-commentary about the camera. 돌아가다 for cameras means "to roll/run," a common expression in media contexts. 아야 되다 expresses obligation/necessity. The 인데 ending suggests the speaker is building up to reveal this important information, creating suspense. The progression from casual questioning (맞나) to formal importance (중대한 사항) shows the speaker's shifting register as they realize the significance.
Sentence 4
전 설마 이렇게 내향 외향으로 갈라서 모일 줄은 몰랐거든요? 그래서 제가 준비했던 게 뭐냐면은
"I never would have thought we'd gather divided like this between introverts and extroverts, you know? So what I had prepared was..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 전 - "I" - 저 (formal I) contracted
• 설마 - "surely not/never would have thought" - Adverb expressing disbelief
• 이렇게 - "like this/in this way" - Adverb
• 내향 - "introversion" - Personality type term
• 외향으로 - "by extroversion" - 외향 (extroversion) + 으로 (by means of/according to)
• 갈라서 - "divided/split" - 갈리다 (to be divided) + 아서 (and then/as a result)
• 모일 줄은 - "would gather" - 모이다 (to gather) + ㄹ 줄 (expectation/assumption) + 은 (topic)
• 몰랐거든요? - "didn't know, you know?" - 모르다 (to not know) + 았 (past) + 거든요 (explanatory/casual ending)
• 그래서 - "so/therefore" - Conjunction
• 제가 - "I (humble)" - 저 (formal I) + 가 (subject particle)
• 준비했던 게 - "what I had prepared" - 준비하다 (to prepare) + 했던 (past descriptive) + 것 (thing)
• 뭐냐면은 - "what it is, is..." - 뭐 (what) + 냐면 (explanatory connector) + 은 (topic)
Grammar Deep Dive: 설마...줄은 몰랐다 is a pattern expressing "never would have thought/expected." The speaker shifts between formal (전→제가) and casual registers, showing social awareness. 거든요 is a very natural Korean ending that provides background information while seeking understanding. 뭐냐면은 is a connector that introduces an explanation, building suspense before revealing what was prepared.
Sentence 5
내향형은 무조건 기가 빨린다 외향형들 사이에서 기 빨리고 너무 피곤한데
"Introverts definitely get their energy drained. Among extroverts, they get energy-drained and become so tired."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 내향형은 - "introverts (topic)" - 내향형 (introverted type) + 은 (topic particle)
• 무조건 - "definitely/unconditionally" - Adverb expressing certainty
• 기가 빨린다 - "energy gets drained" - 기 (energy/spirit) + 가 (subject) + 빨리다 (to be sucked out/drained)
• 외향형들 - "extroverts" - 외향형 (extroverted type) + 들 (plural marker)
• 사이에서 - "among/between" - 사이 (between) + 에서 (location/context particle)
• 기 빨리고 - "energy gets drained and" - Same as above + 고 (connector)
• 너무 - "too much/so" - Intensifying adverb
• 피곤한데 - "tired, but" - 피곤하다 (to be tired) + ㄴ데 (explanatory/contrasting ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The repetition of 기 빨리다 emphasizes the core concept - energy drainage. 무조건 adds absolute certainty to the statement, showing the speaker's confidence in this personality theory. The 는데 ending suggests there's more to come, setting up for the solution that follows. This sentence demonstrates how Korean naturally builds explanations through repetition and elaboration rather than complex single statements.
Sentence 6
말은 못 하고 집에 가고 싶고 미쳐 할 것이다 그럴 때 당근을 흔들어라
"They can't speak, want to go home, and will go crazy. In such times, shake the carrot."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 말은 - "speaking (topic)" - 말 (words/speech) + 은 (topic particle)
• 못 하고 - "can't do and" - 못 (cannot) + 하다 (to do) + 고 (connector)
• 집에 - "to home" - 집 (home) + 에 (direction particle)
• 가고 싶고 - "want to go and" - 가다 (to go) + 고 싶다 (want to) + 고 (connector)
• 미쳐 - "go crazy" - 미치다 (to go crazy/mad) stem form
• 할 것이다 - "will do" - 하다 (to do) + ㄹ 것이다 (future tense, formal prediction)
• 그럴 때 - "at such times" - 그렇다 (to be so) + ㄹ 때 (when/at the time)
• 당근을 - "carrot (object)" - 당근 (carrot) + 을 (object particle)
• 흔들어라 - "shake" - 흔들다 (to shake) + 어라 (imperative ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This builds a dramatic sequence using 고 connectors to list the introvert's struggles. The shift from descriptive (못 하고, 가고 싶고) to predictive (할 것이다) creates urgency. The imperative 어라 ending is strong and direct, like a command or rallying cry. "당근을 흔들어라" (shake the carrot) appears to be a metaphorical solution - possibly meaning to offer incentives or motivation to help introverts in social situations.
Sentence 7
당근을 흔들어라 당근을 흔들어라
"Shake the carrot, shake the carrot"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 당근을 - "carrot (object)" - 당근 (carrot) + 을 (object particle)
• 흔들어라 - "shake" - 흔들다 (to shake) + 어라 (imperative ending)
• 당근을 흔들어라 - "shake the carrot" - Exact repetition for emphasis
Grammar Deep Dive: The repetition creates a chant-like quality, emphasizing this as a key strategy or mantra. This appears to be the speaker's coined phrase or method for dealing with introvert energy drainage in social situations. The carrot metaphor likely represents incentive or motivation - something to entice or energize introverts when they're struggling in extroverted environments. The repetition makes it memorable and impactful, like a slogan.
Sentence 1
분명히 기 빨리는데 말은 못 하고 눈치만 보는 내향형이 있을 것이다 너무 괴롭고 집에 가고 싶을 때
"There will definitely be introverts whose energy gets drained but can't speak and just read the room. When they're too distressed and want to go home..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 분명히 - "clearly/definitely" - 분명하다 (to be clear) + 히 (adverb suffix)
• 기 빨리는데 - "energy gets drained, but" - 기 (energy) + 빨리다 (to be drained) + 는데 (contrasting conjunction)
• 말은 - "speaking (topic)" - 말 (words/speech) + 은 (topic particle)
• 못 하고 - "can't do and" - 못 (cannot) + 하다 (to do) + 고 (connector)
• 눈치만 - "only reading the mood" - 눈치 (social awareness/mood reading) + 만 (only)
• 보는 - "watching/reading" - 보다 (to see/watch) + 는 (adjectival ending)
• 내향형이 - "introverts (subject)" - 내향형 (introverted type) + 이 (subject particle)
• 있을 것이다 - "there will be" - 있다 (to exist) + ㄹ 것이다 (future/prediction)
• 너무 - "too much/so" - Intensifying adverb
• 괴롭고 - "distressed/tormented and" - 괴롭다 (to be distressed) + 고 (connector)
• 집에 - "to home" - 집 (home) + 에 (direction particle)
• 가고 싶을 때 - "when wanting to go" - 가다 (to go) + 고 싶다 (want to) + ㄹ 때 (when)
Grammar Deep Dive: 눈치 보다 is a crucial Korean concept meaning "to read the room/social atmosphere" - a key aspect of Korean social interaction. The sentence structure builds empathy by describing the introvert's internal struggle: energy drained (기 빨리는데) but unable to express it (말은 못 하고), leading to passive observation (눈치만 보는). The use of ㄹ 것이다 makes this a prediction about social dynamics, showing the speaker's understanding of personality types.
Sentence 2
당근을 흔들어주세요 아 준비를 열심히 하셨네요 네 귀여워 진짜 당근을 사 오셨어 8개 샀다고요
"Please shake the carrot for them. Ah, you prepared so diligently! Yes, so cute! You really bought carrots - you bought 8 of them?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 당근을 - "carrot (object)" - 당근 (carrot) + 을 (object particle)
• 흔들어주세요 - "please shake (for them)" - 흔들다 (to shake) + 어주다 (to do for someone) + 세요 (polite request)
• 아 - "ah" - Exclamation of realization
• 준비를 - "preparation (object)" - 준비 (preparation) + 를 (object particle)
• 열심히 - "diligently/hard" - Adverb meaning earnestly
• 하셨네요 - "you did (honorific + discovery)" - 하다 (to do) + 셨 (honorific past) + 네요 (discovery/admiration ending)
• 네 - "yes" - Acknowledgment
• 귀여워 - "cute/adorable" - 귀엽다 (to be cute) + 어 (casual ending)
• 진짜 - "really" - Casual intensifier
• 당근을 - "carrots (object)" - Same as above
• 사 오셨어 - "you bought and brought" - 사오다 (to buy and bring) + 셨어 (honorific past casual)
• 8개 - "8 pieces" - Number + counter for items
• 샀다고요 - "you bought?" - 사다 (to buy) + 았다고 (reported speech) + 요 (polite questioning)
Grammar Deep Dive: 어주다 adds nuance of doing something for someone's benefit - here suggesting shaking carrots to help introverts. 하셨네요 shows pleasant surprise and admiration using honorifics. The progression from formal request (흔들어주세요) to casual excitement (귀여워) shows natural emotional response. 사오다 specifically means "to buy and bring" - more specific than just "to buy," showing thoughtful action.
Sentence 3
당근 근데 왜 이렇게 커요? 몰라 나 당근이 이렇게 큰지 몰랐어 브라질산인가? 먹을래? 어 그래 먹자
"Carrots... but why are they so big? I don't know, I didn't know carrots could be this big. Are they from Brazil? Want to eat some? Uh, yeah, let's eat."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 당근 - "carrots" - Noun (used as topic here without particle)
• 근데 - "but/by the way" - Casual contraction of 그런데
• 왜 - "why" - Question word
• 이렇게 - "like this/so" - Demonstrative adverb
• 커요? - "are they big?" - 크다 (to be big) + 어요 (polite ending)
• 몰라 - "I don't know" - 모르다 (to not know) + 아 (casual ending)
• 나 - "I" - First person pronoun (casual)
• 당근이 - "carrots (subject)" - 당근 (carrot) + 이 (subject particle)
• 이렇게 큰지 - "how big/that they're this big" - 이렇게 (this much) + 크다 (big) + ㄴ지 (indirect question)
• 몰랐어 - "didn't know" - 모르다 (to not know) + 았어 (past casual)
• 브라질산인가? - "are they from Brazil?" - 브라질산 (Brazilian-made) + 인가 (questioning ending)
• 먹을래? - "want to eat?" - 먹다 (to eat) + ㄹ래 (casual intention/suggestion)
• 어 - "uh" - Hesitation/filler word
• 그래 - "yeah/okay" - Casual agreement
• 먹자 - "let's eat" - 먹다 (to eat) + 자 (suggestion ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows natural conversational flow with topic shifts. ㄴ지 모르다 pattern expresses not knowing about a fact or situation. 산 (産) means "produced in" when attached to country names. The conversation moves from surprise (왜 이렇게 커요?) to speculation (브라질산인가?) to action (먹을래?). The casual register throughout (몰라, 먹을래, 그래) shows comfortable familiarity between speakers.
Sentence 4
사실 어딜 들어가도 상관이 없어 어 맞어 왔다 누가 온 거죠? 미션이요
"Actually, it doesn't matter where we go. Uh, that's right, someone came. Who came? It's a mission."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 사실 - "actually/in fact" - Adverb
• 어딜 - "where (object)" - 어디 (where) + 를 (object particle, contracted)
• 들어가도 - "even if we go into" - 들어가다 (to go into) + 도 (even if)
• 상관이 - "relation/concern (subject)" - 상관 (relation/concern) + 이 (subject particle)
• 없어 - "there isn't" - 없다 (to not exist) + 어 (casual ending)
• 어 - "uh" - Filler word
• 맞어 - "that's right" - 맞다 (to be correct) + 어 (casual ending)
• 왔다 - "came" - 오다 (to come) + 았다 (past declarative)
• 누가 - "who (subject)" - 누구 (who) + 가 (subject particle)
• 온 거죠? - "came?" - 오다 (to come) + ㄴ 것 (nominalizing) + 죠 (confirmation seeking)
• 미션이요 - "it's a mission" - 미션 (mission) + 이다 (to be) + 요 (polite ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 상관없다 is a common expression meaning "it doesn't matter/no problem." The 도 particle creates a concessive meaning "even if." The sudden topic shift (왔다, 누가 온 거죠?) shows reactive conversation typical in Korean dialogue. 죠 ending seeks confirmation or agreement from the listener. The mention of 미션 suggests this is content creation or entertainment context.
Sentence 5
엄마다 엄마! 어? 누가 왔어
"It's mom! Mom! Huh? Who came?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 엄마다 - "it's mom" - 엄마 (mom) + 다 (declarative ending, casual/excited)
• 엄마! - "Mom!" - Direct address with exclamation
• 어? - "huh?/what?" - Interjection showing confusion or surprise
• 누가 - "who (subject)" - 누구 (who) + 가 (subject particle)
• 왔어 - "came" - 오다 (to come) + 았어 (past casual)
Grammar Deep Dive: The 다 ending here expresses excitement or sudden realization, more emphatic than neutral statement endings. The repetition of 엄마 shows the emotional reaction to seeing mother. The questioning sequence (어? 누가 왔어) suggests confusion about the situation, possibly because others don't recognize who arrived. This shows natural family interaction patterns in Korean.
Sentence 6
엄마 왔어
"Mom came."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 엄마 - "mom" - Familiar term for mother
• 왔어 - "came" - 오다 (to come) + 았어 (past casual ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This simple sentence provides clarification after the confusion in the previous sentence. The casual ending (왔어) rather than polite (왔어요) indicates either speaking to someone of equal/lower status or in a very comfortable family setting. The brevity emphasizes the straightforward nature of the information being conveyed.
Sentence 7
안녕하세요 어? 에드머님 안녕하세요 안녕하세요
"Hello. Huh? Edmer-nim, hello. Hello."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 안녕하세요 - "hello" - Standard polite greeting
• 어? - "huh?" - Interjection of surprise or confusion
• 에드머님 - "Edmer-nim" - Name + honorific suffix showing respect
• 안녕하세요 - "hello" - Repeated greeting (recognition)
• 안녕하세요 - "hello" - Third repetition (reciprocal greeting)
Grammar Deep Dive: The progression shows recognition and social adjustment. First 안녕하세요 is general greeting, 어? shows surprise at recognizing someone specific, then addressing 에드머님 directly with respect (님 honorific), followed by exchange of greetings. The multiple repetitions of 안녕하세요 are natural in Korean social interactions, especially when there's a moment of recognition or when multiple people are greeting each other. This demonstrates proper Korean greeting etiquette with appropriate honorific usage.
Sentence 1
안녕하세요! 누구.. 누구예요? 에드머님 있는데? 맞은편에? 몰라
"Hello! Who... who is it? Edmer-nim is there? On the opposite side? I don't know."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 안녕하세요! - "hello!" - Standard polite greeting with excitement
• 누구.. - "who..." - 누구 (who) with trailing off (hesitation/uncertainty)
• 누구예요? - "who is it?" - 누구 (who) + 예요 (polite copula for questions)
• 에드머님 - "Edmer-nim" - Name + honorific suffix
• 있는데? - "is there, but?" - 있다 (to exist/be) + 는데 (contrasting/questioning ending)
• 맞은편에? - "on the opposite side?" - 맞은편 (opposite side) + 에 (location particle)
• 몰라 - "I don't know" - 모르다 (to not know) + 아 (casual ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows confusion and uncertainty through fragmented speech patterns. The repetition of 누구 (누구.. 누구예요?) demonstrates natural Korean speech when processing information. 있는데 with rising intonation turns a statement into a questioning confirmation. The shift from polite greeting to casual 몰라 shows the speaker's comfort level changing as confusion increases.
Sentence 2
누구야? 아 그 아 그 뭐라고 해야 되지 재밌으신 분 있어요 자 두 번째 미션입니다
"Who is it? Ah that, ah that, how should I say... there's an entertaining person. Now, this is the second mission."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 누구야? - "who is it?" - 누구 (who) + 야 (casual question ending)
• 아 그 - "ah that" - Filler words showing hesitation in description
• 아 그 - "ah that" - Repeated hesitation pattern
• 뭐라고 - "what/how" - 뭐 (what) + 라고 (quotative particle)
• 해야 되지 - "should I say" - 하다 (to do/say) + 아야 되다 (should) + 지 (questioning/pondering)
• 재밌으신 - "entertaining/funny (honorific)" - 재미있다 (to be fun) + 으신 (honorific adjectival ending)
• 분 - "person (respectful)" - Honorific counter for people
• 있어요 - "there is" - 있다 (to exist) + 어요 (polite ending)
• 자 - "now/well" - Attention-getting interjection
• 두 번째 - "second" - 두 (two) + 번째 (ordinal suffix)
• 미션입니다 - "it's a mission" - 미션 (mission) + 입니다 (formal copula)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker struggles to describe someone, shown through repetitive hesitation (아 그 아 그). 뭐라고 해야 되지 is a common pattern meaning "how should I put it/say this." The use of honorifics (재밌으신 분) shows respect while describing someone. The transition marker 자 signals a shift to official announcement mode, reflected in the formal 입니다 ending.
Sentence 3
뭘까? 내려오세요
"What could it be? Please come down."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 뭘까? - "what could it be?" - 뭐 (what) + ㄹ까 (wondering/speculation ending)
• 내려오세요 - "please come down" - 내려오다 (to come down) + 세요 (polite imperative)
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄹ까 ending expresses speculation or wondering, often used when anticipating something unknown. The short, direct command 내려오세요 suggests someone in authority giving instructions, typical in organized activities or shows. The contrast between wondering (뭘까) and directing (내려오세요) shows different speakers or a quick shift in situation.
Sentence 4
다들 내려와주세요 두 번째 미션을 공개한다 다섯 시 십 분까지
"Everyone please come down. I'm revealing the second mission. Until 5:10."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 다들 - "everyone" - 다 (all) + 들 (plural marker, casual/inclusive)
• 내려와주세요 - "please come down" - 내려오다 (to come down) + 아주다 (to do for someone) + 세요 (polite request)
• 두 번째 - "second" - 두 (two) + 번째 (ordinal suffix)
• 미션을 - "mission (object)" - 미션 (mission) + 을 (object particle)
• 공개한다 - "I reveal/announce" - 공개하다 (to reveal/disclose) + ㄴ다 (declarative ending, formal/authoritative)
• 다섯 시 - "5 o'clock" - 다섯 (five) + 시 (hour/time)
• 십 분까지 - "until 10 minutes" - 십 분 (10 minutes) + 까지 (until/by)
Grammar Deep Dive: 아주다 adds a nuance of doing something for others' benefit, making the request more considerate. The ㄴ다 ending in 공개한다 is formal and authoritative, often used in announcements or official statements. Time expressions like 다섯 시 십 분까지 show precise scheduling typical in organized activities. The progression from polite request to formal announcement shows role-based language use.
Sentence 5
옆 방 사람들과 저녁식사를 같이 준비할 한 명을 선정해주세요 선정된 MBTI는
"Please select one person to prepare dinner together with the people from the next room. The selected MBTI will..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 옆 방 - "next room" - 옆 (next/side) + 방 (room)
• 사람들과 - "with people" - 사람들 (people) + 과 (with)
• 저녁식사를 - "dinner (object)" - 저녁식사 (dinner) + 를 (object particle)
• 같이 - "together" - Adverb meaning "together/with"
• 준비할 - "to prepare" - 준비하다 (to prepare) + ㄹ (future/intention adjectival)
• 한 명을 - "one person (object)" - 한 명 (one person) + 을 (object particle)
• 선정해주세요 - "please select" - 선정하다 (to select) + 아주다 (for benefit) + 세요 (polite request)
• 선정된 - "selected" - 선정하다 (to select) + 된 (passive adjectival ending)
• MBTI는 - "MBTI (topic)" - MBTI + 는 (topic particle)
Grammar Deep Dive: This shows formal instruction language typical in organized activities. The structure 준비할 한 명을 선정해주세요 uses future adjectival form (ㄹ) to describe the purpose of the person being selected. The passive construction 선정된 MBTI emphasizes the result of the selection process. Using "MBTI" instead of "person" shows how personality types have become identity markers in this context.
Sentence 6
안내 방송이 나오면 즉시 반대편 방으로 이동해주세요 선정된 MBTI는
"When the announcement comes out, please immediately move to the opposite room. The selected MBTI will..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 안내 - "guidance/announcement" - Noun referring to informational broadcast
• 방송이 - "broadcast (subject)" - 방송 (broadcast) + 이 (subject particle)
• 나오면 - "when it comes out" - 나오다 (to come out) + 면 (conditional "when/if")
• 즉시 - "immediately" - Adverb expressing urgency
• 반대편 - "opposite side" - 반대 (opposite) + 편 (side/direction)
• 방으로 - "to the room" - 방 (room) + 으로 (direction particle)
• 이동해주세요 - "please move" - 이동하다 (to move) + 아주다 (for benefit) + 세요 (polite request)
• 선정된 - "selected" - 선정하다 (to select) + 된 (passive adjectival)
• MBTI는 - "MBTI (topic)" - MBTI + 는 (topic particle)
Grammar Deep Dive: The conditional 면 structure creates a sequence of events - when X happens, do Y. 즉시 emphasizes the urgency and importance of timing. The repetition of 선정된 MBTI는 creates suspense by building up to reveal what will happen to the selected person. This formal instructional language shows organized activity management typical in Korean variety shows or structured group activities.
Sentence 7
반대편 사람들과 함께 식사를 합니다 헐 세상에
"You will eat together with the people from the opposite side. Whoa, oh my god."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 반대편 - "opposite side" - 반대 (opposite) + 편 (side)
• 사람들과 - "with people" - 사람들 (people) + 과 (with)
• 함께 - "together" - Adverb, more formal than 같이
• 식사를 - "meal (object)" - 식사 (meal) + 를 (object particle)
• 합니다 - "will do/have" - 하다 (to do) + ㅂ니다 (formal polite ending)
• 헐 - "whoa/what" - Interjection expressing shock or surprise
• 세상에 - "oh my god/goodness" - 세상 (world) + 에 (particle), idiomatic exclamation
Grammar Deep Dive: The formal 합니다 ending maintains the official announcement tone. The sudden shift to informal exclamations (헐 세상에) shows participants' immediate emotional reactions to the mission details. 헐 is a modern Korean interjection expressing shock, while 세상에 is a more traditional expression of amazement. This contrast shows the blend of contemporary and traditional Korean expressions in modern speech.
Sentence 8
한 명 보내는 거네요? 네 맞네 트레이드 되네
"So you're sending one person? Yes, that's right. It's like a trade."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 한 명 - "one person" - 한 (one) + 명 (counter for people)
• 보내는 거네요? - "you're sending?" - 보내다 (to send) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 네요 (realization/confirmation)
• 네 - "yes" - Affirmative response
• 맞네 - "that's right" - 맞다 (to be correct) + 네 (realization ending)
• 트레이드 - "trade" - English loanword
• 되네 - "it becomes" - 되다 (to become) + 네 (realization ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 네 ending shows realization or discovery about a situation. The progression from questioning confirmation (거네요?) to agreement (맞네) to conceptual understanding (트레이드 되네) shows how Korean speakers process and confirm information. Using English "트레이드" shows how business/gaming terminology has entered Korean casual conversation to describe social dynamics.
Sentence 9
한 명 가야 돼요 한 명 옆방에 보낸대요 그럼 어떻게 뽑을까요 우리? 이거 무슨 기준으로 뽑아야 되는 거지?
"One person has to go. They're sending one person to the next room. Then how should we pick, us? What criteria should we use to pick this?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 한 명 - "one person" - 한 (one) + 명 (counter for people)
• 가야 돼요 - "has to go" - 가다 (to go) + 아야 되다 (must/have to) + 요 (polite)
• 한 명 - "one person" - Repeated for emphasis
• 옆방에 - "to the next room" - 옆방 (next room) + 에 (direction particle)
• 보낸대요 - "they're sending" - 보내다 (to send) + ㄴ대요 (hearsay/indirect information)
• 그럼 - "then" - 그러면 (if so) contracted
• 어떻게 - "how" - Question word for method
• 뽑을까요 - "shall we pick?" - 뽑다 (to pick/select) + ㄹ까요 (suggestion/questioning)
• 우리? - "us?" - First person plural with questioning tone
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun (casual)
• 무슨 - "what kind of" - Question word for type/kind
• 기준으로 - "by what criteria" - 기준 (standard/criteria) + 으로 (by means of)
• 뽑아야 되는 거지? - "should we pick?" - 뽑다 (to pick) + 아야 되다 (should) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 지 (questioning/pondering)
Grammar Deep Dive: ㄴ대요 ending conveys information heard from others, showing the speaker is relaying what they understand about the rules. The rhetorical questioning pattern (뽑을까요 우리? 뽑아야 되는 거지?) shows group decision-making process in Korean. The repetition of 한 명 emphasizes the constraint. 기준으로 뽑다 is a common construction for selection based on criteria, showing systematic thinking about group dynamics.
Sentence 1
가위바위보 해야 될 거 같아 뽑아 주는 거예요 저희가 가는 거예요? 잠깐 제가 봤을 때는 이게
"I think we should do rock-paper-scissors. Are they picking for us? Are we the ones going? Wait, from what I saw, this is..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 가위바위보 - "rock-paper-scissors" - Traditional Korean game for decision-making
• 해야 될 거 같아 - "I think we should do" - 하다 (to do) + 아야 되다 (should) + ㄹ 것 같다 (seems like)
• 뽑아 주는 거예요 - "are they picking for us?" - 뽑다 (to pick) + 아주다 (to do for someone) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 예요 (polite copula)
• 저희가 - "we (humble)" - 저희 (we, humble) + 가 (subject particle)
• 가는 거예요? - "are we going?" - 가다 (to go) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 예요 (polite questioning)
• 잠깐 - "wait/hold on" - Interjection to pause conversation
• 제가 - "I (humble)" - 저 (I, humble) + 가 (subject particle)
• 봤을 때는 - "when I looked/from what I saw" - 보다 (to see) + 았을 때 (when) + 는 (topic)
• 이게 - "this is" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject, contracted)
Grammar Deep Dive: 가위바위보 is the standard Korean method for fair decision-making in groups. The ㄹ 것 같다 pattern expresses opinion or speculation. The confusion shown through multiple questions (뽑아 주는 거예요? 가는 거예요?) demonstrates uncertainty about who has agency in the situation. 잠깐 serves as a discourse marker to introduce a correction or new perspective.
Sentence 2
정리왕 믿고 있다구 제가 봤을 땐 보세요 여러분
"I'm trusting the organization king. From what I see, look everyone."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 정리왕 - "organization king" - 정리 (organization/arrangement) + 왕 (king) - nickname for someone good at organizing
• 믿고 있다구 - "I'm trusting/believing" - 믿다 (to trust) + 고 있다 (continuous) + 다구 (emphatic casual ending)
• 제가 - "I (humble)" - 저 (I, humble) + 가 (subject particle)
• 봤을 땐 - "from what I saw" - 보다 (to see) + 았을 때 (when) + 는 (topic, contracted)
• 보세요 - "look/see" - 보다 (to see) + 세요 (polite imperative)
• 여러분 - "everyone" - Polite way to address multiple people
Grammar Deep Dive: 정리왕 shows Korean tendency to create playful titles by combining descriptive words with 왕 (king). The 다구 ending is emphatic and slightly informal, showing strong conviction. The speaker uses formal address (여러분) while maintaining casual conviction markers, showing social awareness in group settings. This demonstrates leadership communication patterns in Korean group dynamics.
Sentence 3
옆방 사람 넘어갈 사람 한 명을 구하는 거잖아요? 그렇죠 그러면은 꼭 요리할 사람이 아니어도 돼
"We're looking for one person to cross over to the next room, right? That's right. Then it doesn't have to be someone who will cook."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 옆방 - "next room" - 옆 (next/side) + 방 (room)
• 사람 - "person" - Noun
• 넘어갈 - "to cross over" - 넘어가다 (to cross over/go across) + ㄹ (future/adjectival)
• 사람 - "person" - Repeated for specification
• 한 명을 - "one person (object)" - 한 명 (one person) + 을 (object particle)
• 구하는 거잖아요? - "we're looking for, right?" - 구하다 (to seek/look for) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 잖아요 (confirmation seeking)
• 그렇죠 - "that's right" - 그렇다 (to be so) + 죠 (confirmation/agreement)
• 그러면은 - "then/if so" - 그러면 (then) + 은 (topic, adding emphasis)
• 꼭 - "necessarily/definitely" - Adverb expressing requirement
• 요리할 - "to cook" - 요리하다 (to cook) + ㄹ (future/adjectival)
• 사람이 - "person (subject)" - 사람 (person) + 이 (subject particle)
• 아니어도 돼 - "doesn't have to be" - 아니다 (to not be) + 어도 되다 (it's okay even if)
Grammar Deep Dive: 잖아요 seeks confirmation by presenting information as already known or obvious. 넘어가다 means "to cross over" physically or metaphorically. The logical progression 그렇죠 → 그러면은 shows Korean reasoning patterns. 아니어도 되다 is a common construction meaning "it's fine even if not" - used to expand possibilities or reduce requirements.
Sentence 4
극강의 E를 보낼까? 이게 조화를 잘 시켜주실 수 있으실 분을
"Should we send the ultimate E? Someone who can create harmony well..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 극강의 - "ultimate/extreme" - 극강 (extreme strength) + 의 (possessive)
• E를 - "E (object)" - MBTI extroversion + 를 (object particle)
• 보낼까? - "shall we send?" - 보내다 (to send) + ㄹ까 (suggestion/questioning)
• 이게 - "this is" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject, contracted)
• 조화를 - "harmony (object)" - 조화 (harmony) + 를 (object particle)
• 잘 - "well" - Adverb meaning skillfully
• 시켜주실 수 있으실 - "can make happen (honorific)" - 시키다 (to make happen) + 어주다 (for benefit) + 실 수 있다 (can, honorific) + 실 (additional honorific)
• 분을 - "person (object, respectful)" - 분 (honorific person) + 을 (object particle)
Grammar Deep Dive: 극강의 E shows how MBTI terminology has become casual Korean - "extreme E" refers to highly extroverted person. The multiple honorifics (시켜주실 수 있으실) show great respect for the person's social abilities. 조화를 시키다 means "to create harmony" - acknowledging extroverts' social facilitation skills. This reflects Korean understanding of personality types as strategic resources for group dynamics.
Sentence 5
텃세가 있을 거 같은데 내가 갔다 올게 지금 바로 가시는 거예요?
"I think there might be territorialism, but I'll go and come back. Are you going right now?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 텃세가 - "territorialism (subject)" - 텃세 (territorial behavior/cliquishness) + 가 (subject particle)
• 있을 거 같은데 - "I think there might be" - 있다 (to exist) + ㄹ 것 같다 (seems like) + 는데 (but/contrasting)
• 내가 - "I (casual)" - 나 (I) + 가 (subject particle)
• 갔다 올게 - "I'll go and come back" - 가다 (to go) + 았다 오다 (go and return) + ㄹ게 (intention/promise)
• 지금 - "now" - Time adverb
• 바로 - "right away/immediately" - Adverb for immediacy
• 가시는 거예요? - "are you going?" - 가다 (to go) + 시 (honorific) + 는 것 (nominalizing) + 예요 (polite question)
Grammar Deep Dive: 텃세 is a uniquely Korean concept describing territorial/exclusive behavior, especially when outsiders join established groups. 갔다 오다 specifically means "to go and return" - acknowledging the temporary nature of the visit. The shift from casual self-reference (내가) to honorific other-reference (가시는) shows appropriate Korean social register adjustment. ㄹ게 expresses firm intention or promise.
Sentence 6
아니면 뭐 가고 싶으신 분 있으세요? 아 가기 별로 좀 그런가요?
"Or is there anyone who wants to go? Ah, is going not really appealing?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니면 - "or/otherwise" - 아니다 (to not be) + 면 (if)
• 뭐 - "well/what" - Filler word, casual transition
• 가고 싶으신 - "wanting to go (honorific)" - 가다 (to go) + 고 싶다 (want to) + 으신 (honorific adjectival)
• 분 - "person (respectful)" - Honorific counter for people
• 있으세요? - "is there?" - 있다 (to exist) + 으세요 (honorific question)
• 아 - "ah" - Interjection of realization
• 가기 - "going" - 가다 (to go) + 기 (nominalizing suffix)
• 별로 - "not really/not particularly" - Adverb expressing lack of enthusiasm
• 좀 - "a bit/somewhat" - Adverb for mild degree
• 그런가요? - "is it like that?" - 그렇다 (to be so) + ㄴ가요 (questioning ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker uses consistent honorifics (가고 싶으신 분, 있으세요) when asking for volunteers, showing respect for others' choices. 별로 followed by 좀 그런가요 is an indirect way to acknowledge reluctance without being direct - typical Korean politeness strategy. The progression from direct question to indirect observation shows sensitivity to group dynamics and face-saving.
Sentence 7
지금 가고 싶으신 분? 궁금하기는 한데? 어 진짜 가고 싶으신 분은 제가
"Anyone who wants to go now? I am curious though? Uh, for those who really want to go, I will..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 지금 - "now" - Time adverb
• 가고 싶으신 분? - "person who wants to go?" - 가다 (to go) + 고 싶다 (want to) + 으신 분 (honorific person)
• 궁금하기는 한데? - "I am curious though?" - 궁금하다 (to be curious) + 기는 하다 (although/admitting) + 는데 (but)
• 어 - "uh" - Hesitation/filler word
• 진짜 - "really" - Intensifier (casual)
• 가고 싶으신 분은 - "person who wants to go (topic)" - Same as above + 은 (topic particle)
• 제가 - "I (humble)" - 저 (I, humble) + 가 (subject particle)
Grammar Deep Dive: 기는 하다 pattern acknowledges one thing while introducing a contrast - "I do admit I'm curious, but..." This shows internal conflict between curiosity and hesitation. The repetition of 가고 싶으신 분 with different particles (분? vs 분은) shows the speaker refining their target audience. The trailing 제가 suggests the speaker is building up to offer something, creating suspense in group decision-making.
Sentence 8
궁금하긴 한데 무섭기도 하고 약간 공포 반 두려움 반이야 한 명만 간다고 그러니까 조금
"I am curious, but it's also scary. It's like half fear, half dread. Since they say only one person goes, it's a bit..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 궁금하긴 한데 - "I am curious, but" - 궁금하다 (to be curious) + 긴 하다 (although) + 는데 (but)
• 무섭기도 하고 - "it's also scary" - 무섭다 (to be scary) + 기도 하다 (also) + 고 (and)
• 약간 - "somewhat/slightly" - Adverb for degree
• 공포 - "fear/terror" - Noun
• 반 - "half" - Fraction/portion
• 두려움 - "dread/anxiety" - Noun, deeper fear than 공포
• 반이야 - "half" - 반 (half) + 이다 (to be) + 야 (casual ending)
• 한 명만 - "only one person" - 한 명 (one person) + 만 (only)
• 간다고 - "they say goes" - 가다 (to go) + ㄴ다고 (reported speech)
• 그러니까 - "so/therefore" - Causal connector
• 조금 - "a little" - Adverb for small degree
Grammar Deep Dive: 긴 하다 is a stronger version of 기는 하다, emphasizing the concession. The speaker distinguishes between 공포 (immediate fear) and 두려움 (deeper anxiety/dread), showing emotional sophistication.
