Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니 근데 - "but wait" - 아니 (no/wait) + 근데 (but, casual form of 그런데)
• 밥 준비를 - "meal preparation (object)" - 밥 (meal) + 준비 (preparation) + 를 (object particle)
• 같이 - "together" - Adverb
• 하라 그랬는데 - "they said to do" - 하다 (to do) + 라 (imperative) + 그러다 (to say) + 았는데 (past + contrasting)
Grammar Deep Dive: "하라 그랬다" is indirect quotation of a command - "they told us to do." The 는데 ending suggests this conflicts with the current situation. The speaker is reminding others of earlier instructions about cooking together.
Sentence 5
진짜 다 드셨어요? 식사를 하셨어요?
"Did you really eat everything? Did you have your meal?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 진짜 - "really/truly" - Adverb for emphasis
• 다 - "all/everything" - Adverb meaning completely
• 드셨어요? - "did you eat?" - 드시다 (to eat, honorific) + 셨어요 (honorific past polite)
• 식사를 하셨어요? - "did you have a meal?" - 식사 (meal, formal) + 를 (object) + 하다 (to do) + 셨어요 (honorific past polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: Double-checking with both casual (다 드셨어요) and formal (식사를 하셨어요) ways of asking about eating. This shows concern about meal timing and planning. The repetition emphasizes the speaker's surprise or concern.
Sentence 6
저희는 오자마자 밥부터 먹었습니다
"We ate rice first as soon as we arrived"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 저희는 - "we (humble)" - 저희 (we, humble) + 는 (topic particle)
• 오자마자 - "as soon as we came" - 오다 (to come) + 자마자 (as soon as)
• 밥부터 - "rice/meal first" - 밥 (rice/meal) + 부터 (starting from/first)
• 먹었습니다 - "ate" - 먹다 (to eat) + 었습니다 (past formal polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: "자마자" indicates immediate sequence - "as soon as X, then Y." "부터" emphasizes that eating was the very first priority. The formal ending 습니다 adds politeness while explaining their actions.
Sentence 7
뭐 드셨어요 그러면은?
"What did you eat then?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 뭐 - "what" - Interrogative pronoun
• 드셨어요 - "did you eat" - 드시다 (to eat, honorific) + 셨어요 (honorific past polite)
• 그러면은 - "then/in that case" - 그러면 (then) + 은 (topic particle, redundant but common in speech)
Grammar Deep Dive: Adding "은" after "그러면" is grammatically redundant but very common in casual speech for emphasis. The question follows logically from learning they already ate - now asking for details.
Sentence 8
저희 그냥 계란말이에다 스팸 구워가지고
"We just grilled SPAM with rolled eggs"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 저희 - "we (humble)" - First person plural humble
• 그냥 - "just" - Adverb minimizing/casualizing
• 계란말이에다 - "with rolled eggs" - 계란말이 (rolled omelet) + 에다 (with/to)
• 스팸 - "SPAM" - English loanword for canned meat
• 구워가지고 - "grilled and" - 굽다 (to grill) + 어가지고 (having done/and so)
Grammar Deep Dive: "에다" is colloquial for "에" (with/to). "가지고" shows sequence and causation. SPAM is very popular in Korean cuisine. The sentence structure suggests this was a simple, casual meal.
Sentence 9
누가 하셨어요?
"Who made it?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 누가 - "who (subject)" - 누구 (who) + 가 (subject particle)
• 하셨어요? - "did (someone) do?" - 하다 (to do) + 셨어요 (honorific past polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: Simple question asking who did the cooking. The honorific form shows respect for whoever did the work. This is natural follow-up curiosity about meal preparation.
Sentence 10
제가 귀하신 분이 오셨네
"I... an honored person has come"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 제가 - "I (humble subject)" - 저 (I, humble) + 가 (subject particle)
• 귀하신 분이 - "honored person (subject)" - 귀하다 (precious/honored) + 신 (honorific modifier) + 분 (person, honorific) + 이 (subject particle)
• 오셨네 - "has come" - 오다 (to come) + 셨다 (honorific past) + 네 (discovery/mild surprise)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker starts to say they cooked (제가) but gets distracted by someone's arrival. "귀하신 분" is very respectful language for an honored guest. The 네 ending shows pleasant surprise at the person's arrival.
Sentence 11
저희는 부대찌개를 할 건데
"We're going to make budae-jjigae (army stew)"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 저희는 - "we (humble)" - 저희 (we, humble) + 는 (topic particle)
• 부대찌개를 - "budae-jjigae (object)" - 부대찌개 (army stew) + 를 (object particle)
• 할 건데 - "going to do" - 하다 (to do) + ㄹ 것이다 (will/going to) + 는데 (background info)
Grammar Deep Dive: 부대찌개 (budae-jjigae) is a popular Korean stew with SPAM, sausages, and vegetables - perfect for group cooking. The 는데 ending provides background information, suggesting they're explaining their cooking plans.
Sentence 12
라면 스프를 넣어가지고
"Adding ramyeon soup base and"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 라면 - "ramyeon" - Korean instant noodles
• 스프를 - "soup base (object)" - 스프 (soup, from English) + 를 (object particle)
• 넣어가지고 - "adding and" - 넣다 (to put in) + 어가지고 (having done/and so)
Grammar Deep Dive: Using ramyeon soup packets is a common way to flavor budae-jjigae. "가지고" shows this is part of a sequence of cooking steps. This demonstrates typical Korean fusion cooking techniques.
Sentence 13
라면 스프면 다 되죠
"With ramyeon soup base, it's all done, right?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 라면 스프면 - "if it's ramyeon soup base" - 라면 스프 + 면 (if/with)
• 다 되죠 - "it's all done, right?" - 다 (all/completely) + 되다 (to become/be done) + 죠 (confirmatory)
Grammar Deep Dive: "면" here means "with" or "if you use." The speaker is suggesting that ramyeon soup base is sufficient to complete the dish. The 죠 ending seeks agreement about this cooking shortcut.
Sentence 14
그걸 주면 어떡해
"What if we give them that?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그걸 - "that thing (object)" - 그것 (that) + 을 (object particle) contracted
• 주면 - "if we give" - 주다 (to give) + 면 (if)
• 어떡해 - "what should we do/what would happen" - 어떻게 하다 contracted
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker is considering offering their simple food to the guest. "어떡해" here suggests concern about whether their simple meal would be appropriate for an honored guest.
Sentence 15
뭐 어떤 어떤 거... 아니 뭐 김치 하나만 주셔도 맛있게 먹는데
"What, what kind of thing... No, well, even if you just give us one kimchi, we'd eat it deliciously"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 뭐 어떤 어떤 거... - "what, what kind of thing..." - Hesitant, searching for words
• 아니 뭐 - "no, well" - Discourse markers showing reconsideration
• 김치 하나만 - "just one kimchi" - 김치 (kimchi) + 하나 (one) + 만 (only/just)
• 주셔도 - "even if you give" - 주다 (to give) + 셔도 (honorific + even if)
• 맛있게 먹는데 - "eat deliciously" - 맛있게 (deliciously) + 먹다 (to eat) + 는데 (contrasting/but)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker is being very humble, saying even just kimchi would be enough. "도" emphasizes "even if." The hesitant beginning shows politeness about making requests. This demonstrates Korean courtesy in host-guest interactions.
Sentence 16
김치도 안 주시니까...
"Since you're not even giving us kimchi..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 김치도 - "even kimchi" - 김치 (kimchi) + 도 (even/also)
• 안 주시니까... - "since you're not giving" - 안 (not) + 주다 (to give) + 시니까 (honorific + because) + trailing off
Grammar Deep Dive: The sentence trails off with "..." suggesting disappointment or complaint. "도" emphasizes that even the most basic side dish (kimchi) isn't being provided. This shows subtle criticism wrapped in polite language.
Sentence 17
같이 요리를 해야 되는데
"We need to cook together though"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 같이 - "together" - Adverb
• 요리를 - "cooking (object)" - 요리 (cooking/cuisine) + 를 (object particle)
• 해야 되는데 - "need to do but" - 하다 (to do) + 야 되다 (need to) + 는데 (contrasting)
Grammar Deep Dive: "해야 되다" expresses obligation/necessity. The 는데 ending suggests this obligation conflicts with the current situation (guests having already eaten). The speaker is reminding about the original plan.
Sentence 18
김치 있어요 같이 요리를...
"There's kimchi, cooking together..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 김치 있어요 - "there's kimchi" - 김치 (kimchi) + 있다 (to exist) + 어요 (polite)
• 같이 요리를... - "cooking together..." - 같이 (together) + 요리 (cooking) + 를 (object) + trailing off
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker discovers kimchi is available and starts suggesting they cook together, but the sentence is interrupted or incomplete. This shows the dynamic, spontaneous nature of the conversation.
Sentence 19
김치 이거 종갓집이라 맛있어
"This kimchi is from Jongga (brand), so it's delicious"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 김치 - "kimchi" - Korean fermented cabbage dish
• 이거 - "this" - Demonstrative pronoun
• 종갓집이라 - "it's Jongga brand" - 종갓집 (Jongga, kimchi brand) + 이라 (copula)
• 맛있어 - "it's delicious" - 맛있다 (to be delicious) + 어 (casual ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 종갓집 (Jongga) is a well-known Korean kimchi brand. "이라" is a casual form of "이다" (to be). The speaker is vouching for the quality by mentioning the brand name, showing Korean consumer awareness.
Sentence 20
아니면 소세지를 좀
"Or some sausages"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니면 - "or/if not" - Conjunction offering alternative
• 소세지를 - "sausages (object)" - 소세지 (sausage, from English) + 를 (object particle)
• 좀 - "a bit/some" - Adverb meaning a little
Grammar Deep Dive: "좀" softens requests and makes them more polite. The sentence is incomplete, likely continuing with a verb like "주다" (to give). Sausages are common in budae-jjigae, so this fits the cooking context.
Sentence 21
아 소세지 스팸이나 이런 거
"Ah, sausages, SPAM or things like that"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아 - "ah" - Exclamation of realization
• 소세지 - "sausages" - English loanword
• 스팸이나 - "SPAM or" - 스팸 (SPAM) + 이나 (or, listing alternatives)
• 이런 거 - "things like this" - 이런 (this kind of) + 거 (thing)
Grammar Deep Dive: "이나" is used for listing alternatives or examples. "이런 거" indicates "things of this type." The speaker is clarifying what ingredients they're talking about for the stew.
Sentence 22
라면도 하나 드릴까요?
"Should I give you one ramyeon too?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 라면도 - "ramyeon too" - 라면 (ramyeon) + 도 (also/too)
• 하나 - "one" - Number/counter
• 드릴까요? - "shall I give?" - 드리다 (to give, humble) + ㄹ까요 (propositive polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: "드리다" is the humble form of "주다" (to give), showing respect to the recipient. The speaker is offering to contribute ramyeon to the group cooking effort. "도" indicates this is in addition to other ingredients.
Sentence 23
아니면은 간단하게 뭐 볶음밥
"Or simply, what, fried rice"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니면은 - "or" - 아니면 (or/if not) + 은 (redundant topic particle)
• 간단하게 - "simply" - 간단하다 (simple) + 게 (adverbial ending)
• 뭐 - "what/well" - Filler word showing hesitation
• 볶음밥 - "fried rice" - 볶다 (to stir-fry) + 음 (nominalizer) + 밥 (rice)
Grammar Deep Dive: "간단하게" suggests looking for an easier cooking option. "뭐" shows the speaker is thinking aloud. Fried rice is a simple dish that can accommodate various ingredients, making it perfect for group cooking.
Sentence 24
김치 드리면... 볶음밥
"If we give kimchi... fried rice"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 김치 드리면... - "if we give kimchi..." - 김치 (kimchi) + 드리다 (to give, humble) + 면 (if) + trailing pause
• 볶음밥 - "fried rice" - 볶다 (to stir-fry) + 음 (nominalizer) + 밥 (rice)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker is thinking through the logic - if they provide kimchi, they could make kimchi fried rice. The pause indicates they're working out the cooking plan. Kimchi fried rice is a popular Korean comfort food.
Sentence 25
아니면은 저거에다 밥 말아먹으면
"Or if we mix rice with that"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니면은 - "or" - 아니면 (or/if not) + 은 (redundant topic particle)
• 저거에다 - "with that" - 저거 (that thing) + 에다 (with/to, colloquial)
• 밥 말아먹으면 - "if we mix rice and eat" - 밥 (rice) + 말다 (to mix/roll) + 아 먹다 (eat) + 으면 (if)
Grammar Deep Dive: "말아먹다" literally means "roll and eat" but here means mixing rice with soup or stew. This is a common way to eat Korean stews - mixing rice directly into the broth. "저거" refers to the stew they're planning.
Sentence 26
그렇게 맛있다고 들었는데
"I heard it's delicious like that"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그렇게 - "like that/in that way" - Adverb
• 맛있다고 - "saying it's delicious" - 맛있다 (delicious) + 다고 (quotative)
• 들었는데 - "I heard but" - 듣다 (to hear) + 었는데 (past + contrasting)
Grammar Deep Dive: "다고 들었다" is a common pattern for reporting hearsay - "I heard that..." The 는데 ending suggests they're considering whether to try this based on what they've heard. This shows Korean food culture knowledge sharing.
Sentence 27
그래요? 저게 뭐야?
"Really? What is that?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그래요? - "is that so?/really?" - 그렇다 (to be so) + 아요 (polite questioning)
• 저게 - "that thing (subject)" - 저것 (that) + 이 (subject particle) contracted
• 뭐야? - "what is it?" - 뭐 (what) + 이다 (to be) + 야 (casual questioning)
Grammar Deep Dive: "그래요?" expresses surprise or requests confirmation. The shift from polite (그래요) to casual (뭐야) shows the speaker becoming more engaged and curious. They're asking about something they can see but don't recognize.
Sentence 28
피토틱스 옐로우 팩이랑 이게 밥도둑이라고 하더라고요
"The Fitotix yellow pack and this, they say it's a 'rice thief' (so delicious you eat lots of rice)"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 피토틱스 옐로우 팩이랑 - "with Fitotix yellow pack" - Brand name + 이랑 (with/and)
• 이게 - "this (subject)" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject particle) contracted
• 밥도둑이라고 - "saying it's a rice thief" - 밥도둑 (rice thief) + 이라고 (quotative copula)
• 하더라고요 - "they say" - 하다 (to say) + 더라 (retrospective/hearsay) + 고요 (polite ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: "밥도둑" (rice thief) is Korean slang for food so delicious it makes you eat lots of rice. "더라고" indicates the speaker heard/learned this from someone else. This shows Korean food culture where side dishes are evaluated by how well they go with rice.
Sentence 1
아이 진짜 뿌리지 말고 하실 수 있으면 바꿔드릴게요 왜 이렇게 가만히 계세요
"Oh really, don't scatter it. If you can do it, I'll change it for you. Why are you staying so still like this?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아이 - "oh" - Exclamation expressing mild frustration
• 진짜 - "really/truly" - Adverb for emphasis
• 뿌리지 말고 - "don't scatter and" - 뿌리다 (to scatter) + 지 말다 (don't) + 고 (and)
• 하실 수 있으면 - "if you can do" - 하다 (to do) + 실 수 있다 (honorific ability) + 으면 (if)
• 바꿔드릴게요 - "I'll change it for you" - 바꾸다 (to change) + 어 드리다 (humble give) + ㄹ게요 (promise)
• 왜 이렇게 - "why like this" - 왜 (why) + 이렇게 (like this)
• 가만히 계세요 - "staying still" - 가만히 (still/quietly) + 계시다 (honorific be) + 어요 (polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: Multiple sentences combined. "드리다" shows humble service. "가만히 있다" means staying still/inactive. The speaker seems to be offering help while wondering why someone is being so passive.
Sentence 2
왜 이렇게 확 바뀌었어 아까랑 보는 것 만으로 기 빨려요 확 달라지셨네
"Why did it change so dramatically like this? Just from looking compared to earlier, my energy is being drained. You've really changed dramatically"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 왜 이렇게 - "why like this" - 왜 (why) + 이렇게 (like this)
• 확 - "dramatically/suddenly" - Adverb for sudden change
• 바뀌었어 - "changed" - 바뀌다 (to change) + 었어 (past casual)
• 아까랑 - "compared to earlier" - 아까 (earlier) + 랑 (with/compared to)
• 보는 것 만으로 - "just from looking" - 보다 (to see) + 는 것 (nominalizer) + 만으로 (just by)
• 기 빨려요 - "energy is being drained" - 기 (energy/spirit) + 빨리다 (to be sucked out) + 어요 (polite)
• 달라지셨네 - "you've changed" - 달라지다 (to become different) + 셨다 (honorific past) + 네 (discovery)
Grammar Deep Dive: "확" emphasizes sudden change. "만으로" means "just by/only with." "기 빨려" is colloquial for feeling drained. The 네 ending shows observing someone's behavioral change with mild surprise.
Sentence 3
보는 것 만으로 기 빨려 계속 고생하겠네요 저 쪽에서 이렇게 해서 이렇게 하는 건가요?
"Just from looking, my energy is being drained. You'll keep having a hard time. Is that how they do it over there, doing it like this and like that?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 보는 것 만으로 - "just from looking" - 보다 (to see) + 는 것 (nominalizer) + 만으로 (just by)
• 기 빨려 - "energy is being drained" - 기 (energy) + 빨리다 (to be sucked out) casual
• 계속 - "continuously" - Adverb meaning ongoing
• 고생하겠네요 - "will have a hard time" - 고생하다 (to suffer) + 겠다 (future) + 네요 (empathetic)
• 저 쪽에서 - "over there/from that side" - 저 쪽 (over there) + 에서 (from)
• 이렇게 해서 이렇게 하는 건가요? - "doing like this and like that?" - 이렇게 (like this) + 하다 (to do) + questioning structure
Grammar Deep Dive: Repeats the energy drain theme. "겠네요" shows empathetic prediction. The vague "이렇게...이렇게" suggests confusion about unclear processes or methods being observed.
Sentence 4
I 방에는 우리 계열의 사람들이 많이 없어요? 맞아 궁금했어
"Aren't there many people from our field in Room I? Right, I was curious about that"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• I 방에는 - "in Room I" - I (letter) + 방 (room) + 에는 (in + topic)
• 우리 계열의 - "our field/type of" - 우리 (our) + 계열 (field/category) + 의 (possessive)
• 사람들이 - "people (subject)" - 사람 (person) + 들 (plural) + 이 (subject)
• 많이 없어요? - "aren't there many?" - 많이 (many) + 없다 (not exist) + 어요 (polite questioning)
• 맞아 - "that's right" - 맞다 (to be correct) + 아 (casual)
• 궁금했어 - "I was curious" - 궁금하다 (to be curious) + 았어 (past casual)
Grammar Deep Dive: "계열" refers to field, category, or type. The negative question expects a positive answer. "맞아" shows agreement and "궁금했어" admits shared curiosity about the same topic.
Sentence 5
I like it 좋아요!
"I like it! I like it!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• I like it - English phrase used directly
• 좋아요! - "I like it!" - 좋다 (to be good/like) + 아요 (polite) + enthusiastic tone
Grammar Deep Dive: Code-switching between English and Korean is common in modern Korean conversation. The repetition in both languages emphasizes enthusiasm and adds international flair to the expression.
Sentence 6
우실 것 같아 많이 계세요?
"It seems like you'll cry. Are there many (of you)?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 우실 것 같아 - "seems like you'll cry" - 울다 (to cry) + 실 (honorific future) + 것 같다 (seems like) casual
• 많이 계세요? - "are there many?" - 많이 (many) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 어요 (polite questioning)
Grammar Deep Dive: The honorific "우실" shows respect while observing emotional state. Could be sympathetic concern or noting someone moved to tears. The second question asks about quantity of people in a group.
Sentence 7
직업은 아직 안 물어봤나? 아니요 다 자기소개 했어요 유튜버 분도 계시고
"Haven't we asked about occupations yet? No, everyone did self-introductions. There's also a YouTuber"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 직업은 - "occupation (topic)" - 직업 (job) + 은 (topic particle)
• 아직 안 물어봤나? - "haven't asked yet?" - 아직 (yet) + 안 (not) + 물어보다 (to ask) + 았나 (past questioning)
• 아니요 - "no" - Polite negation
• 다 자기소개 했어요 - "everyone did self-introductions" - 다 (all) + 자기소개 (self-introduction) + 했어요 (past polite)
• 유튜버 분도 계시고 - "there's also a YouTuber" - 유튜버 (YouTuber) + 분 (person, honorific) + 도 (also) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 고 (and)
Grammar Deep Dive: "자기소개" is compound: 자기 (self) + 소개 (introduction). "분" is honorific for people. This explains they already know occupations through introductions, then starts listing professions.
Sentence 8
모델 분도 계시고 모델이요? 모델이요 모델
"There's also a model. A model? A model? A model"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 모델 분도 계시고 - "there's also a model" - 모델 (model) + 분 (person, honorific) + 도 (also) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 고 (and)
• 모델이요? - "a model?" - 모델 (model) + 이에요 (copula polite) questioning tone
• 모델이요 - "a model" - Same but confirmatory
• 모델 - "model" - Repeated for emphasis
Grammar Deep Dive: Continues listing professions. The repetition shows surprise and excitement about having a model in the group. Progression from questioning to confirmation to simple repetition shows processing of interesting information.
Sentence 9
남자예요 여자예요? 여자분이세요 너무 좋아 멋있겠다 완전 멋있어요
"Are they male or female? It's a female. So cool! That must be awesome. Totally cool"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 남자예요 여자예요? - "male or female?" - 남자 (man) + 예요, 여자 (woman) + 예요 (copula polite)
• 여자분이세요 - "it's a female" - 여자 (woman) + 분 (person, honorific) + 이세요 (copula honorific)
• 너무 좋아 - "so good/cool" - 너무 (so/too) + 좋다 (good) + 아 (casual)
• 멋있겠다 - "must be cool/awesome" - 멋있다 (cool) + 겠다 (assumption)
• 완전 멋있어요 - "totally cool" - 완전 (completely) + 멋있다 (cool) + 어요 (polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: Direct gender question followed by respectful answer using "분." "겠다" expresses assumption about how cool the profession must be. "완전" is modern slang for "totally."
Sentence 10
정말 다양하게 그냥 총 통틀어서 16명을 엄청 다양하게
"Really diversely. Just in total, all 16 people very diversely"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 정말 다양하게 - "really diversely" - 정말 (really) + 다양하다 (diverse) + 게 (adverb ending)
• 그냥 - "just" - Casual adverb
• 총 통틀어서 - "in total/altogether" - 총 (total) + 통틀다 (to include all) + 어서 (and)
• 16명을 - "16 people (object)" - 16 + 명 (counter for people) + 을 (object particle)
• 엄청 다양하게 - "very diversely" - 엄청 (tremendously) + 다양하게 (diversely)
Grammar Deep Dive: "통틀어서" means including everything together. The speaker is impressed by how diverse the selection of 16 people is across different backgrounds and professions.
Sentence 11
데려온 것 같아요 여기에는 댄서 강사 분도 계시고 댄서 분 계세요?
"It seems like they brought (people). Here there's also a dance instructor. Is there a dancer?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 데려온 것 같아요 - "seems like they brought" - 데려오다 (to bring people) + ㄴ 것 같다 (seems like) + 아요 (polite)
• 여기에는 - "here" - 여기 (here) + 에는 (at + topic)
• 댄서 강사 분도 계시고 - "there's also a dance instructor" - 댄서 (dancer) + 강사 (instructor) + 분 (person, honorific) + 도 (also) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 고 (and)
• 댄서 분 계세요? - "is there a dancer?" - 댄서 (dancer) + 분 (person, honorific) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 어요 (polite questioning)
Grammar Deep Dive: "데려오다" specifically means bringing people. "댄서 강사" combines profession with role. The question distinguishes between dance instructor and professional dancer.
Sentence 12
수학 선생님 계시고 수학 선생님이요? 여기 중에 계시는데 누가 수학 선생님일 것 같아요?
"There's a math teacher. A math teacher? They're among us here, but who do you think is the math teacher?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 수학 선생님 계시고 - "there's a math teacher" - 수학 (math) + 선생님 (teacher) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 고 (and)
• 수학 선생님이요? - "a math teacher?" - 수학 선생님 + 이에요 (copula polite) questioning
• 여기 중에 계시는데 - "they're among us here, but" - 여기 (here) + 중 (among) + 에 (in) + 계시다 (honorific exist) + 는데 (contrasting)
• 누가 수학 선생님일 것 같아요? - "who do you think is the math teacher?" - 누가 (who) + 수학 선생님 + 일 것 같다 (seems like will be) + 아요 (polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: "선생님" always takes honorific forms. Creates a guessing game asking others to identify who among visible people might be the math teacher. "일 것 같다" expresses assumption about identity.
Sentence 13
저 네 명 중에 있어요
"They're among those four people"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 저 - "those" - Demonstrative pronoun for distant objects
• 네 명 - "four people" - 네 (four) + 명 (counter for people)
• 중에 - "among" - Among/within
• 있어요 - "there is/they are" - 있다 (to exist) + 어요 (polite)
Grammar Deep Dive: Narrows down the guessing game by pointing to a specific group of four people. This creates suspense and engages others in trying to figure out who has which profession based on appearance.
Sentence 1
모르겠어요 그래도 한번 그냥 찍어봐봐요
"I don't know, but still, just try guessing once"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 모르겠어요 - "I don't know" - 모르다 (to not know) + 겠 (uncertainty/conjecture) + 어요 (polite ending)
• 그래도 - "but still/even so" - Conjunction expressing contrast despite circumstances
• 한번 - "once/one time" - Counter for frequency, here meaning "give it a try"
• 그냥 - "just/simply" - Adverb meaning casually or without special reason
• 찍어봐봐요 - "try guessing" - 찍다 (to guess/pick randomly) + 어보다 (try doing) + 봐요 (casual polite imperative)
Grammar Deep Dive: The double 봐 in 찍어봐봐요 is a casual spoken form where 봐요 (polite imperative "please do") is combined with 어보다 (try doing). This creates a friendly, encouraging tone. 찍다 originally means "to poke/stab" but in casual contexts means "to guess randomly" especially on tests.
Sentence 2
아아 아니에요 방금 가셨던 남자분 정말요? 제일 아닌 것... 그쵸
"Oh no, the man who just left, really? The most inappropriate one... right?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아아 - "oh oh" - Interjection expressing realization or surprise
• 아니에요 - "no/that's not it" - 아니다 (to not be) + 에요 (polite ending)
• 방금 - "just now/a moment ago" - Adverb for recent past
• 가셨던 - "who went/left" - 가다 (to go) + 시 (honorific) + 었 (past) + 던 (retrospective modifier)
• 남자분 - "gentleman/man" - 남자 (man) + 분 (honorific counter for people)
• 정말요? - "really?" - 정말 (really) + 요 (polite question ending)
• 제일 - "the most" - Superlative adverb
• 아닌 것 - "the wrong one/inappropriate one" - 아니다 (to not be) + ㄴ (modifier) + 것 (thing)
• 그쵸 - "right?/isn't it?" - Contracted form of 그렇죠, seeking agreement
Grammar Deep Dive: 가셨던 uses the retrospective 던 to refer back to someone who left earlier. The honorific 시 shows respect for the person being discussed. The sentence trails off with 제일 아닌 것... showing hesitation or avoiding direct criticism. 그쵸 is a very casual contraction seeking validation from the listener.
Sentence 3
원래 본인이 이런 사람인데 뭘 그거를 아니 제가 딱 제가 갈게요! 이러고 가면은 뭔가 좀 아~
"Originally this person is like this, but what... that thing... no, if I just say 'I'll go!' and leave, it feels somewhat... ah~"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 원래 - "originally/by nature" - Adverb indicating inherent characteristics
• 본인이 - "this person (subject)" - 본인 (the person themselves) + 이 (subject particle)
• 이런 사람인데 - "is this kind of person, but" - 이런 (this kind of) + 사람 (person) + 인데 (but/however)
• 뭘 - "what" - Contracted form of 무엇을
• 그거를 - "that thing" - 그것 (that thing) + 을 (object particle)
• 아니 - "no" - Interjection of disagreement or correction
• 제가 - "I (humble subject)" - 저 (humble I) + 가 (subject particle)
• 딱 - "exactly/just" - Adverb for precision or emphasis
• 갈게요! - "I'll go!" - 가다 (to go) + ㄹ게요 (intention/promise ending)
• 이러고 - "doing this/saying this" - 이렇다 (to be like this) + 고 (and then)
• 가면은 - "if I go" - 가다 (to go) + 면 (if/when) + 은 (topic emphasis)
• 뭔가 - "something/somehow" - 뭔가 (something indefinite)
• 좀 - "a bit/somewhat" - Adverb for degree, often softening statements
• 아~ - "ah~" - Extended interjection showing uncertainty or trailing off
Grammar Deep Dive: This is stream-of-consciousness speech with multiple false starts and corrections. The speaker uses 인데 to set up contrast, then gets distracted with 뭘 그거를 (filler words while thinking). 딱 emphasizes the decisiveness of saying "I'll go!" but then 가면은 with the emphatic 은 shows they're reconsidering. The trailing 아~ shows internal conflict about the decision.
Sentence 4
아니 나는 MBTI가 원래 이게 아니라고 생각했어 E라고 생각한 거지
"No, I thought my MBTI wasn't originally this. I thought it was E, you know"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니 - "no" - Interjection expressing disagreement or clarification
• 나는 - "I (casual subject)" - 나 (casual I) + 는 (topic particle)
• MBTI가 - "MBTI (subject)" - Myers-Briggs Type Indicator + 가 (subject particle)
• 원래 - "originally/by nature" - Adverb for inherent state
• 이게 - "this thing" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject particle) contracted
• 아니라고 - "is not" - 아니다 (to not be) + 라고 (quotation particle)
• 생각했어 - "I thought" - 생각하다 (to think) + 았 (past tense) + 어 (casual ending)
• E라고 - "as E" - Letter E + 라고 (quotation/identification particle)
• 생각한 거지 - "I thought, you know" - 생각하다 (to think) + ㄴ (past modifier) + 거 (thing/fact) + 지 (confirmatory ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker switches from polite to casual speech (했어, 거지), showing they're becoming more comfortable or emotional about the topic. E라고 refers to the Extrovert designation in MBTI. The 거지 ending seeks agreement/understanding from the listener, like "you know what I mean?" This reveals personal vulnerability about self-perception vs. test results.
Sentence 5
그러니까 저도 사람들이 자꾸 E일 거 같다 그래가지고
"So I also... people keep saying I seem like I'd be E, so..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그러니까 - "so/therefore" - Conjunction showing cause and effect
• 저도 - "I also" - 저 (humble I) + 도 (also/too particle)
• 사람들이 - "people (subject)" - 사람들 (people) + 이 (subject particle)
• 자꾸 - "keep/repeatedly" - Adverb indicating continuous action
• E일 거 같다 - "seem like would be E" - E + 일 것 (will be) + 같다 (seem like)
• 그래가지고 - "so/and so" - Casual conjunction, contraction of 그래서 가지고
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker returns to humble speech (저도) when mentioning others' opinions, showing respect for social perception. 자꾸 emphasizes the repeated nature of people's comments. 일 거 같다 expresses others' assumptions about the speaker's personality type. 그래가지고 is very casual and shows the speaker trailing off, implying more context follows.
Sentence 6
이게 만약에 신청해서 와서 검사받았는데 다른 MBTI가 나오면 안 되잖아요
"If this... if I applied and came and took the test, but a different MBTI came out, that wouldn't be good, you know"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 이게 - "this thing" - 이것 (this) + 이 (subject particle) contracted
• 만약에 - "if/in case" - Conditional conjunction with emphasis particle
• 신청해서 - "applied and" - 신청하다 (to apply) + 해서 (and then)
• 와서 - "came and" - 오다 (to come) + 아서 (and then)
• 검사받았는데 - "took the test, but" - 검사받다 (to receive a test) + 았 (past) + 는데 (but/however)
• 다른 - "different/other" - Adjective modifying MBTI
• MBTI가 - "MBTI (subject)" - Personality test + 가 (subject particle)
• 나오면 - "if it comes out" - 나오다 (to come out/appear) + 면 (if/when)
• 안 되잖아요 - "it won't work/wouldn't be good" - 안 되다 (won't work) + 잖아요 (obvious fact ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This sentence shows the speaker's anxiety about consistency. The sequence 신청해서 와서 검사받았는데 creates a narrative flow of actions leading to a problem. 잖아요 indicates the speaker expects the listener to agree that getting different results would be problematic, suggesting social pressure to maintain consistent personality typing.
Sentence 7
그래서 좀 긴장했는데 ISTP 똑같이 나오더라고
"So I was a bit nervous, but ISTP came out exactly the same"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 그래서 - "so/therefore" - Conjunction showing result
• 좀 - "a bit/somewhat" - Adverb softening the degree
• 긴장했는데 - "was nervous, but" - 긴장하다 (to be nervous) + 했 (past) + 는데 (but/however)
• ISTP - "ISTP" - Myers-Briggs personality type (Introverted, Sensing, Thinking, Perceiving)
• 똑같이 - "exactly the same" - Adverb emphasizing identical results
• 나오더라고 - "came out (I discovered)" - 나오다 (to come out) + 더라고 (personal discovery/realization ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: 더라고 is a key ending that expresses the speaker's personal discovery or realization about something they witnessed or experienced. It often conveys mild surprise or interest in sharing this new information. The speaker seems relieved that their results were consistent, validating their self-perception as an introvert despite others' assumptions.
Sentence 8
근데 생각대로 안 됐어요 당황스러워서 근데 생각대로 안 됐어요 당황스러워서
"But it didn't go as I thought, I was flustered, but it didn't go as I thought, I was flustered"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 근데 - "but/however" - Casual conjunction, contraction of 그런데
• 생각대로 - "as I thought/as planned" - 생각 (thought) + 대로 (according to/as)
• 안 됐어요 - "didn't work out" - 안 되다 (not work) + 었어요 (past polite)
• 당황스러워서 - "because I was flustered" - 당황스럽다 (to be flustered) + 어서 (because/so)
Grammar Deep Dive: The repetition of the entire phrase indicates the speaker is either emphasizing their confusion or actually repeating themselves due to being flustered. This kind of repetition is common in emotional or stressful speech. 당황스럽다 specifically means feeling confused and overwhelmed, different from just being nervous or surprised.
Sentence 9
다음화 예고 부아앙
"Next episode preview - waaah!"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 다음화 - "next episode" - 다음 (next) + 화 (episode/chapter)
• 예고 - "preview/announcement" - Noun for advance notice
• 부아앙 - "waaah!" - Onomatopoeia for crying or emotional outburst
Grammar Deep Dive: This appears to be mimicking TV show format announcements. 부아앙 is a cute, childish way of expressing crying or emotional distress, often used humorously. The context suggests this might be from a variety show or someone playfully narrating their life like a TV drama.
Sentence 10
이거 말하는 거지? 부앙 부앙 부앙 부앙 부앙
"You're talking about this, right? Wah wah wah wah wah"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 이거 - "this thing" - Pronoun referring to nearby object/topic
• 말하는 거지? - "talking about, right?" - 말하다 (to speak) + 는 (present modifier) + 거 (thing) + 지 (confirmatory ending)
• 부앙 - "wah" - Onomatopoeia for crying, repeated 5 times for emphasis
Grammar Deep Dive: The repetition of 부앙 five times creates a rhythmic, almost musical quality that's very characteristic of Korean entertainment or playful speech. The 거지 ending seeks confirmation while the crying sounds suggest either genuine distress or dramatic/comedic exaggeration.
Sentence 11
매출 백프로 증가! 이것도 궁금하다 지금의 저쪽 조용히 방 안에서 나갈까요?
"Sales increased 100 percent! This is also curious. Should we quietly leave the room over there now?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 매출 - "sales/revenue" - Business term for income from sales
• 백프로 - "100 percent" - 백 (hundred) + 프로 (percent, from English "pro")
• 증가! - "increase!" - Noun with exclamation for emphasis
• 이것도 - "this also" - 이것 (this) + 도 (also particle)
• 궁금하다 - "is curious/interesting" - Adjective expressing curiosity
• 지금의 - "current/present" - 지금 (now) + 의 (possessive particle)
• 저쪽 - "over there" - Demonstrative for distant location
• 조용히 - "quietly" - Adverb from 조용하다 (to be quiet)
• 방 안에서 - "from inside the room" - 방 (room) + 안 (inside) + 에서 (from/at location)
• 나갈까요? - "shall we leave?" - 나가다 (to go out) + ㄹ까요 (shall we suggestion ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: This sentence seems to jump between topics - from business success to curiosity to suggesting leaving. The 백프로 is a casual way to say 100%, mixing Korean and English. The suggestion 나갈까요 is polite and inclusive, asking for group consensus about leaving quietly, possibly to avoid disrupting something.
Sentence 12
아니 달라고 안 했잖아요 아니 내가 달라고 그랬잖아요
"No, I didn't ask for it, you know. No, I did ask for it, you know"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 아니 - "no" - Interjection expressing disagreement
• 달라고 - "to give/asking for" - 달다 (to give) + 라고 (quotation particle)
• 안 했잖아요 - "didn't do, you know" - 안 하다 (not do) + 잖아요 (obvious fact ending)
• 내가 - "I (subject)" - 나 (I) + 가 (subject particle)
• 그랬잖아요 - "did that, you know" - 그러다 (to do so) + 았 (past) + 잖아요 (obvious fact ending)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker contradicts themselves within the same sentence, first denying they asked for something, then immediately admitting they did. Both uses of 잖아요 appeal to shared knowledge, but create confusion since the statements contradict. This suggests either confusion, changing their story, or referring to different contexts.
Sentence 13
귀엽다고 근데 더! 귀엽다는 말이 달라는 말이었어요?
"I said cute, but more! Was saying 'cute' the same as asking for it?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 귀엽다고 - "saying it's cute" - 귀엽다 (to be cute) + 다고 (quotation ending)
• 근데 - "but" - Casual conjunction
• 더! - "more!" - Adverb with exclamation for emphasis
• 귀엽다는 말이 - "the words 'it's cute'" - 귀엽다 (cute) + 는 말 (the words/saying) + 이 (subject)
• 달라는 말이었어요? - "was it the same as asking for it?" - 달라 (give) + 는 말 (saying) + 이었어요 (was it, polite question)
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker is clarifying a miscommunication - they said something was "cute" but the listener interpreted this as a request. The 다고 and 다는 말 constructions both refer to reported speech or quotations. This reveals confusion about implied meanings in conversation, showing how indirect communication can lead to misunderstandings.
Sentence 14
나는 그거까지 함축적으로 포함했었는데 이해를 못 한 거예요? 네...
"I had implicitly included that much, but you didn't understand? Yes..."
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 나는 - "I (topic)" - 나 (I) + 는 (topic particle)
• 그거까지 - "up to that/that much" - 그것 (that) + 까지 (up to/even)
• 함축적으로 - "implicitly" - Adverb meaning indirectly or by implication
• 포함했었는데 - "had included, but" - 포함하다 (to include) + 았었 (past perfect) + 는데 (but)
• 이해를 - "understanding (object)" - 이해 (understanding) + 를 (object particle)
• 못 한 거예요? - "couldn't do?" - 못 하다 (cannot do) + ㄴ 거예요 (explanatory question ending)
• 네... - "yes..." - Polite agreement with trailing uncertainty
Grammar Deep Dive: The speaker claims they had implicitly communicated their request, using 함축적으로 (a sophisticated word for "implicitly"). The past perfect 했었는데 emphasizes they had already done this action before. The trailing 네... suggests resignation or acceptance of the misunderstanding. This shows frustration with indirect communication styles common in Korean culture.
Sentence 15
경쟁이야 우리?ㅋㅋㅋ 어 뭐야
"Is this competition between us? Hahaha, uh, what?"
Detailed Word Analysis:
• 경쟁이야 - "is competition" - 경쟁 (competition) + 이야 (casual "is" ending)
• 우리? - "us/we?" - Pronoun for "we/us" in question form
• ㅋㅋㅋ - "hahaha" - Korean onomatopoeia for laughter (keyboard sound)
• 어 - "uh/huh" - Interjection showing surprise or pause
• 뭐야 - "what" - Casual question word expressing confusion or surprise
Grammar Deep Dive: The casual 이야 ending and ㅋㅋㅋ laughter suggest a playful, friendly tone despite mentioning competition. ㅋㅋㅋ specifically represents the Korean keyboard sound for laughter (ㅋ = "k" sound). The sequence 어 뭐야 shows sudden confusion or reaction to something unexpected, very natural in casual conversation.
